[{'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2019-06-06 09:35:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2019-06-06 09:37:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-25 22:26:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

As I started reading this, I *thought* you were going to say:

Create a separate place to store chunks of flavor metadata, so you could effectively "modularize" extra_specs. The "modules" would be groupings of key/value pairs that are logically associated with each other, but not necessarily associated with other "modules". Then either by listing them by name/ID in the flavor, or specifying them directly to the boot request, you could customize your instance without having to repeat the same information in multiple flavors, or have "flavor explosion" where many almost-identical flavors exist that only differ in small ways.

Which I thought would be a pretty nice idea.

But all I see here is a table where arbitrary key/value pairs can be stored. I don't see any description of how those key/value pairs might be grouped together, or how you associate them with a flavor and/or instance.

I think there's a seed of potential here, but it definitely needs further development.'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2019-06-26 13:09:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

> Create a separate place to store chunks of flavor metadata, so you 
 > could effectively "modularize" extra_specs. The "modules" would be 
 > groupings of key/value pairs that are logically associated with each 
 > other, but not necessarily associated with other "modules". 
 
 This is the central idea of spec :P 

 > But all I see here is a table where arbitrary key/value pairs can
 > be stored. I don't see any description of how those key/value pairs
 > might be grouped together, or how you associate them with a flavor
 > and/or instance.

Yeah, those key/value pairs need to create an associated with the flavor, IMO, ``flavorid`` is ok. 

 > I think there's a seed of potential here, but it definitely needs
 > further development.

Thanks Eric Fried.
Whether it's from our customers or our own OpenStack environment, we think that "flavor" is too strongly related to "extra_specs".
Sometimes we need to create a lot of flavors in the environment, but their memory, disk and the CPU are the same, this is a very annoying thing.
Therefore, long-term development, it is necessary for the flavor to make changes. I hope that you and others can give more comments on **this** spec, to form a perfect flavor modification plan.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-26 16:58:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2019-06-27 00:54:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2019-06-27 04:33:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2019-06-27 07:55:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(3 comments)

Thanks Alex.
That will be addressed.'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2019-06-27 10:17:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-27 19:34:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I still don't see the APIs for groups (modules). (IMO we *only* need APIs for groups, not for individual keys. By far I would expect the most common use case to be groups; if you really need a single key, you can always make a group-of-one.)

I'm also still not seeing discussion of how to associate the groups with flavors.

But mainly:

I don't think this is realistic for Train. Could you please propose it to the backlog/ subdirectory [1] instead?

[1] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/backlog/index.html"}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2019-06-28 10:36:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2019-06-28 10:37:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Thanks Eric Fried.
I discussed it with my OpenStack development team. As specified by the spec, ``flavor_group`` will be associated with the instance when the instance is created, no longer associated with the flavor, and completely decoupled.

Move to this spec to the backlog.
For the current design, please make suggestions to be more perfect, thank you.'}, {'account_id': 30384, 'date': '2019-07-25 05:59:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

Some nontrivial concerns within."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-10-31 20:06:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

(13 comments)

I think this is lacking a ton of detail, or I'm missing it. I'm very fuzzy on what this looks like when it's done, and definitely how we get from here to there. I'm also skeptical of the benefit-vs-complexity of what is described here, as well as whether or not it aims to be too flexible to satisfy the more cloudy operators that need very strict control over what instances look like.

Maintaining a bunch of flavors to provide multiple combinations of, say, memory amounts with numa topologies, is somework, but it's very (very) scriptable and composition of those things is pretty easy to do in operator tooling that defines them.

So, I don't think I like where this is headed, but I also think it's missing too much detail for me to even know what that destination is exactly. Hopefully my questions inline will help flesh some of that out."}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2019-11-03 15:29:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(13 comments)

Thanks Dan, Eric.

I responded to the question and hope that you can learn more details.'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2019-11-03 15:30:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Published edit on patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2019-11-04 09:06:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Published edit on patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-11-04 15:01:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

It will take a lot to get from where this is today to a point where I think it's worth the effort, complexity, and change to the operator and user experiences."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-11-04 17:07:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Code-Review-2

Thanks for the idea, please keep them coming!"}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2019-11-06 06:50:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2019-11-10 15:47:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Published edit on patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2019-11-10 15:53:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

At the Shanghai PTG meeting, we reached the following agreement on this SPEC:
* Do not try to change the model of the flavor in nova code and in the Db.
* Define a "ComposableFlavorBit" (bikeshed on the name please) REST API entity that can hold any kind of flavor bits (extra specs, normal flavor fields), propose some format in the spec for it. This entity can only be created by the Admin by default.
* Extend the server create REST API to allow the end user to specify what "ComposableFlavorBit"s she wants to add to the "base" flavor she used in the create request.
* The nova api then merges the "ComposableFalvorBit"s with the base flavor and embed the resulting flavor object into the instance.
* Do a similar thing for resize

Update on this SPEC, from PTG meeting discussion results [1] and ML [2].
[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/nova-shanghai-ptg
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-November/010643.html'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2019-11-10 15:59:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-11-14 08:29:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

(16 comments)

This spec needs more work.'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2019-11-14 08:55:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Published edit on patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2019-11-14 11:02:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-11-14 12:30:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1

(8 comments)

i think this has a long way to go.
i innitally though you were going a different direction untill i got to the server create line.

i have mofied some of my comments retroactivly to reflect that but i would like to see more detail in this for the usecase you want to solve as im not sure the solution you are proposing is the right one for that problem.'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2019-11-15 01:52:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Thanks gibi.'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2019-11-15 03:47:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

With the db table design I have a different opinion from you, please review the latest patch, if you need improvement, please leave comments.'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2019-11-15 05:41:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2019-11-15 06:02:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2019-11-15 06:45:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-11-18 22:21:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-11-18 23:35:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Code-Review-1

(19 comments)'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-11-19 11:19:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

(8 comments)

I've read back to Dan's and Eric's comments to see if the current -2s are still valid or not. What problems I see from those comments:

Fundamental problems:
* Upgrade path for old flavors to composable flavors. => The proposal discussed on the PTG has the advantage that is does not change any legacy behavior if the admin does not create any composable bits. Also it does not change any existing db model or RPC message. The API addition can be covered in a microversion. So I think the upgrade is pretty OK.

* Conflicting composable bits => To resolve this I suggest that as a first step reject everything where base flavor or any composable bits in the request have the same extra spec. 

* Restricting composability, basically answering the question: Which base flavor can be combined to which composable bit? => Why not allow every combination at the first step. This feature would be opt in for the deployers anyhow. Later the composable bit can have a list of base flavor ids to allow restricting the composability.

Procedural problems
* Who will implement this? I guess it it the spec author
* Who ill review this? If the implementation is limited to the API level and api db level (for the composed bit model) then I don't think this will be a hair review (no rpc, no virt driver changes). So sure you can sign me up to review it.

@Dan, @Eric: Do I understood your problems properly behind your -2s? Can we make steps forward with this or you still feel that this does not worth the effort?

Cheers,
gibi"}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-11-19 15:09:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

> @Dan, @Eric: Do I understood your problems properly behind your -2s? Can we make steps forward with this or you still feel that this does not worth the effort?

Thanks for outlining the design points, gibi. But my -2 was already assuming these things were the intent (esp. "we're not going to change the way flavors work" and "this is 100% opt-in"). My -2 was purely "this isn't worth the effort". IMO we have enough more important things to do, some of which have been waiting for years, that we shouldn't expend resources on this feature.

If there is enough of a dissenting consensus, I will "upgrade" my vote and let this merge with my -1. But I want to wait to do that until the design text is ironed out so I don't have to keep re-voting each PS.

Note, however, that part of my -2 was to signal "don't bother spending a bunch of effort getting the design text ironed out, because this is unlikely to fly for non-design reasons".'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-11-19 15:19:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

(5 comments)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-11-19 16:36:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

> @Dan, @Eric: Do I understood your problems properly behind your
 > -2s? Can we make steps forward with this or you still feel that
 > this does not worth the effort?

I actually don't want compose-able flavors at all, so I'm at least -1 on that as a thing. I understand some do, and so I'm definitely -2 on any proposal that moves to a world where things are only composed (as this spec was initially). IMHO, in order for something like this to proceed, we *must* have control over which flavors can be composed with which bits. Starting off with no restriction is not a better plan to me.

I think the underlying goal of this spec is to supposedly reduce the management overhead of defining flavors with various pieces of advanced extra specs, not just to provide the compose-able nature altogether. I challenge the assertion that this is a good solution to not having some scripts to automate that task and don't want to see us adopt something which I (and seemingly Eric) expect will bring significant complexity.

If a deployer has a private cloud where everything should be compose-able by users (as this spec seemed to assert initially), why not just open up the policy to let users create flavors? Then they can create what they want, delete it them if/when they're finished, and use ansible or bash to template things out?"}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2019-11-20 04:42:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

(8 comments)

Thanks Sean. gibi and all reivewers.

Agree gibi, this step needs to be simplified. In this SPEC, the concept of group/roules will be removed. The first step is to start from key/value and make it an optional feature of the operator.

In any case, I should update SPEC to the latest and live up to the reviewers who made suggestions.'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2019-11-20 04:58:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-11-20 09:26:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

> > @Dan, @Eric: Do I understood your problems properly behind your
 > -2s? Can we make steps forward with this or you still feel that
 > this does not worth the effort?
 > 
 > Thanks for outlining the design points, gibi. But my -2 was already
 > assuming these things were the intent (esp. "we're not going to
 > change the way flavors work" and "this is 100% opt-in"). My -2 was
 > purely "this isn't worth the effort". IMO we have enough more
 > important things to do, some of which have been waiting for years,
 > that we shouldn't expend resources on this feature.
 > 
 > If there is enough of a dissenting consensus, I will "upgrade" my
 > vote and let this merge with my -1. But I want to wait to do that
 > until the design text is ironed out so I don't have to keep
 > re-voting each PS.
 > 
 > Note, however, that part of my -2 was to signal "don't bother
 > spending a bunch of effort getting the design text ironed out,
 > because this is unlikely to fly for non-design reasons".

Thank Eric. I see you point. Personally I or my employer don't need this feature. I get behind it mostly because it seemed valuable for others in the room and I feel that we can contain the implementation impact pretty well. Anyhow I agree that we need a sort of consensus in the team to introduce this new top level concept to nova.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-11-20 10:10:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

> > @Dan, @Eric: Do I understood your problems properly behind your
 > > -2s? Can we make steps forward with this or you still feel that
 > > this does not worth the effort?
 > 
 > I actually don't want compose-able flavors at all, so I'm at least
 > -1 on that as a thing. I understand some do, and so I'm definitely
 > -2 on any proposal that moves to a world where things are only
 > composed (as this spec was initially). IMHO, in order for something
 > like this to proceed, we *must* have control over which flavors can
 > be composed with which bits. Starting off with no restriction is
 > not a better plan to me.

OK. Let's drop the unconstrained idea of mine and try to come up with a solution where the admin can control which bit can be composed to which flavor. Like having a list of flavor ids for each bit and only allow composing the bit to the listed flavors.

 > 
 > I think the underlying goal of this spec is to supposedly reduce
 > the management overhead of defining flavors with various pieces of
 > advanced extra specs, not just to provide the compose-able nature
 > altogether. I challenge the assertion that this is a good solution
 > to not having some scripts to automate that task and don't want to
 > see us adopt something which I (and seemingly Eric) expect will
 > bring significant complexity.

So you counter proposal is to automate flavor creation *on top of* the nova API. In theory such automation can implement composability in a same way giving possibility to the end user to choose from bits, compose them according to admin defined rules, and then this tool can create a flavor in nova as admin. 
This counter proposal looks good to me too. 

@Brin, @Mohamed do you see this as a viable alternative to your use cases?

 > 
 > If a deployer has a private cloud where everything should be
 > compose-able by users (as this spec seemed to assert initially),
 > why not just open up the policy to let users create flavors? Then
 > they can create what they want, delete it them if/when they're
 > finished, and use ansible or bash to template things out?

I think this is a spectrum between use pure flavor and compose everything. Allowing flavor creation for end user is one extreme, while keeping flavor creation as admin only is the other. I can imagine that there is value behind letting the end user compose things but does not allow composing everything.

Anyhow. Let's see what others think about your alternative proposal. 

Thanks Dan.

gibi"}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2019-12-20 09:04:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Patch Set 13 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 29071, 'date': '2020-01-20 01:01:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2020-01-22 00:30:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2020-01-30 18:15:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

Can we abandon this spec and close the blueprint?'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2020-02-05 06:54:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

> Can we abandon this spec and close the blueprint?

Since we can't reach an agreement, we can abandon this SPEC, but this is not the only way to stop the flavor explosion. Perhaps some day in the future, more people will expect this change."}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2020-02-05 06:56:15.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Abandoned because no consensus could be reached.'}]

commit_message:
Add composable flavor properties

This blueprint proposes define a "ComposableFlavorProperties" REST API
entity that can hold any kind of extra specs, and add additional apis for
flavor fragment management. Then extend the server create REST API to allow
the end user to specify the "ComposableFlavorProperties" they want to add to
the base flavor they used in the create request.

This is not strongly associated with flavors, enhancing the reusability of
flavors.

APIImpact

Blueprint: composable-flavor-properties
Change-Id: Ied367a32d3785b29c4ba7b64a04c855c407a38e7

commit_message:
Add "Review-Priority" gerrit label to devstack

This is to align devstack with many other OpenStack projects.
Adapted to devstack (no -1 for branch freeze nor +1 for
a regular important change).

Change-Id: I64fc41d9caaef6cb3fc06df0a5f712d7e2940063

commit_message:
[ussuri][goal] Drop python 2.7 support and testing

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

Complete discussion & schedule can be found in
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010142.html
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Parent tox py36/py37 jobs to openstack-tox-py36/37 so that the correct
interpreter is installed.

Change-Id: I14a01f0a9989195e30c3ed0dadec35490f41bd48

commit_message:
Ensure driver error preventing trunk port deletion is logged

When trunk port deletion is attempted but fails because the driver does
not permit it, the logs do not contain the driver error message that
specifies the precise rationale for preventing the trunk port deletion.
Log it explicitly.

Change-Id: I7ed1a742849dfce9e65b8eb36566112501fb0e39
(cherry picked from commit 3b56299e1fa0b48bd4d674e57be2e289c4c28547)

[{'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2019-10-25 10:12:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2019-10-28 10:01:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Note that with the switch to Python3, most legacy jobs will need touching anyway, so there's overlap between these two goals: You can convert legacy jobs to Zuul v3 *and* to python3."}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-10-28 10:02:08.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-10-28 10:02:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2019-10-28 11:43:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

> Note that with the switch to Python3, most legacy jobs will need
 > touching anyway, so there's overlap between these two goals: You
 > can convert legacy jobs to Zuul v3 *and* to python3.

Maybe that goal can delegate/offload the "convert legacy jobs" part to this goal.'}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2019-10-28 11:43:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-10-28 14:35:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Reading the goal, it's not clear to me what the gain is... How is OpenStack better if every project completes this goal this cycle? Easier to maintain?"}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2019-10-28 14:55:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2019-10-29 16:13:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-10-30 08:57:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2019-11-06 08:48:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Just for the record: I haven't forgotten this, I'm just waiting for a bit more feedback which will (hopefully) follow after the PTG discussion."}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2019-11-15 14:35:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-11-15 16:19:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-11-19 09:01:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

We discussed this during the summit. Grenade was indeed made out of the scope for this, IIRC.'}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2019-11-20 09:20:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Should I split the grenade part to another goal then, or doesn't that migration need to be tracked by a goal?
Should I change the wording here in a way that the grenade native support in zuul v3 is done, and only consider the migration part of it?"}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2019-11-20 09:22:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Also, given the shift to another cycle, would it be worth to reword he "clean project-config" in a way that it's more than a stretch goal (if not a full part of the goal itself)?'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-12-23 06:33:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

(5 comments)

Let's do the greande migration also as part of this goal. This goal is for V cycle so we have ussuri cycle time to make greande jobs ready. If not completed then we can always reiterate over goal before we select it finally.

I agree that 'clean-project-config' should not be part of this goal due to backporting requirements. Doing that as stresh goal is good enough."}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-12-23 06:38:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> Reading the goal, it's not clear to me what the gain is... How is
 > OpenStack better if every project completes this goal this cycle?
 > Easier to maintain?

This is good point. I agree to document that clearly. 
This is mainly for developers' maintainance benefits. This also helps greatly to do other community-wide work/goal where we have to update/work on gate jobs. 
For example, 1. migrating base distro for testing. This is recuring tasks when we will update the testing runtime to test new distro (i did duplicate work while doing xenial to bionic migration on jobs) 2. IPv6 testing goal (different set of work both legacy and zuulv3 native jobs) etc"}, {'account_id': 7198, 'date': '2020-01-07 14:42:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1

I support this.  Looks like there are comments to be addressed yet.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2020-01-08 16:39:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> I support this.  Looks like there are comments to be addressed yet.

I realize I forgot to reply on this. Yeah I am in agreement with Gmann's opinion in here."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2020-01-15 19:35:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1

(2 comments)

> Reading the goal, it's not clear to me what the gain is... How is OpenStack better if every project completes this goal this cycle?

The update in the most recent patch set addresses this well I think - the main advantage would be that nobody needs to maintain devstack-gate any longer. I think that more than justifies making it a goal rather than letting it remain ad hoc."}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2020-01-16 01:22:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2020-01-16 09:47:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(5 comments)'}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2020-01-16 09:55:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2020-01-16 13:59:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Rollcall-Vote+1

Thanks for update. lgtm.'}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2020-01-16 18:18:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2020-01-20 11:34:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

Proposal looks good to me... The only thing I'm unclear on is whether we expect the work to be done by each project team (in which case it's a great community goal), or rather by a distinct group of Zuulv3 specialists (in which case this would work better as a popup-team, especially since the results are not really user-visible).

In particular, I wonder if teams actually have the local expertise to do that work. If most do, then the goal is fine. But in my experience that kind of tool transition was driven more externally than internally in the past... And if all we expect project teams to do is to prioritize reviews, maybe a pop-up team would make a better fit ?"}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2020-01-20 11:42:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> Proposal looks good to me... The only thing I'm unclear on is
 > whether we expect the work to be done by each project team (in
 > which case it's a great community goal), or rather by a distinct
 > group of Zuulv3 specialists (in which case this would work better
 > as a popup-team, especially since the results are not really
 > user-visible).
 > 
 > In particular, I wonder if teams actually have the local expertise
 > to do that work. If most do, then the goal is fine. But in my
 > experience that kind of tool transition was driven more externally
 > than internally in the past... And if all we expect project teams
 > to do is to prioritize reviews, maybe a pop-up team would make a
 > better fit ?

I realistically expect this to be a case-by-case scenario. Some teams have already reported that they are migrating now, which means they know how to do it. After the starting of the goal the idea is to look at the general picture and see where help is needed (which I think is the general idea of any community goal)."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2020-01-20 11:43:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Rollcall-Vote+1

OK, sounds good to me then!'}, {'account_id': 20813, 'date': '2020-01-20 14:02:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

Looks good to me!'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2020-01-20 14:53:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Rollcall-Vote+1

(1 comment)

> or rather by a distinct group of Zuulv3 specialists (in which case this would work better as a popup-team, especially since the results are not really user-visible).

I don't think that follows. Even if a group of specialists were to do all of the work, we still need every team to review and merge the changes otherwise we are maintaining devstack-gate forever. Having a goal ensures that those reviews are properly prioritised. That's consistent with other past goals where e.g. a lot of the patches have been generated automatically by a small team of goal champions."}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2020-01-20 14:59:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2020-01-20 15:01:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2020-01-20 15:02:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2020-01-20 19:38:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2020-01-21 11:51:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

In neutron we are already slowly migrating jobs to zuul v3 and big +1 from me to finally get rid of legacy jobs :)'}, {'account_id': 16708, 'date': '2020-01-21 19:27:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2020-01-22 15:08:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Rollcall-Vote+1

Big +1'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2020-01-23 11:06:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2020-01-28 10:25:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2020-01-29 13:17:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2020-02-05 04:43:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Rollcall-Vote+1 Workflow+1

This proposal already reaches the majority of TC member votes for more than 3 calendar days. Time to approved it.'}]

commit_message:
Remove py27 jobs

Switch to openstack-python3-ussuri-jobs instead of openstack-python-jobs
which means we'll get py3 jobs only.

Partial-Bug: #1861803

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-28 14:57:11.000000000', 'message': 'Add nova cellv2 multicell support

This introduce needed changes to be able to deploy an additional
cell via oooq. If additional_cell is set to true after the
overcloud got deployed the additional cell gets deployed. Todo
this information gets extracted from the overcloud stack, which
is requried as input to the second heat stack, where the additional
cell is managed with. As a reference [1] is the scenario which
is installed adding a single additional cell.

config/general_config/featureset062 is used for the configuration
and config/nodes/1ctlr_1cellctrl_1comp.yml has a nova config
example.

commit_message:
Add nova cellv2 multicell support

This introduce needed changes to be able to deploy an additional
cell via oooq. If additional_cell is set to true after the
overcloud got deployed the additional cell gets deployed. Todo
this information gets extracted from the overcloud stack, which
is requried as input to the second heat stack, where the additional
cell is managed with. As a reference [1] is the scenario which
is installed adding a single additional cell.

config/general_config/featureset063.yml is used for the configuration
and config/nodes/1ctlr_1cellctrl_1comp.yml has a nova config
example.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/tripleo-docs/latest/features/deploy_cellv2_basic.html

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/691688
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/704661

Change-Id: I2de781fcec64e862bde34929547b578d2af0c16c

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-09 19:08:39.000000000', 'message': 'SSC.disks_sizes_bytes handle CapacityBytes is None

In the open ocean, a Redfish service can return a SimpleStorage resource
containing a Device property with its CapacityBytes property set to
null. According to the Distributed Management Task Force (DMTF) schema
for SimpleStorage, the type of CapacityBytes can be either integer or
null [1].

The Dell integrated Dell Remote Access Controller (iDRAC) 9 running
Lifecycle Controller firmware version 3.30.30.30 returns that for a Dell
EMC PowerEdge R740xd containing a Dell HBA 330 12Gbps SAS Host Bus
Adapter Controller (non-RAID), MiniCard (HBA 330 Mini) [2]. The HBA 330
Mini firmware version is 16.17.00.03.

The same was observed against an R740xd running Lifecycle Controller
firmware version 3.34.34.34.

This changes the SimpleStorageCollection.disks_size_bytes property to
process only Disks with CapacityByes not set to None.

[1] https://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/SimpleStorage.v1_2_3.json
[2] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-ironic/%23openstack-ironic.2019-12-11.log.html#t2019-12-11T07:24:17

Change-Id: I57a0074a7f6c4495e7c73a00c87675ea87fdb6e8
Story: 2006918
Task: 37567
(cherry picked from commit 9d01756833ec97a05f301a4fa1e8b2511d7c5c74)
'}]
commit_message:
SSC.disks_sizes_bytes handle CapacityBytes is None

In the open ocean, a Redfish service can return a SimpleStorage resource
containing a Device property with its CapacityBytes property set to
null. According to the Distributed Management Task Force (DMTF) schema
for SimpleStorage, the type of CapacityBytes can be either integer or
null [1].

The Dell integrated Dell Remote Access Controller (iDRAC) 9 running
Lifecycle Controller firmware version 3.30.30.30 returns that for a Dell
EMC PowerEdge R740xd containing a Dell HBA 330 12Gbps SAS Host Bus
Adapter Controller (non-RAID), MiniCard (HBA 330 Mini) [2]. The HBA 330
Mini firmware version is 16.17.00.03.

The same was observed against an R740xd running Lifecycle Controller
firmware version 3.34.34.34.

This changes the SimpleStorageCollection.disks_size_bytes property to
process only Disks with CapacityByes not set to None.

[1] https://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/SimpleStorage.v1_2_3.json
[2] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-ironic/%23openstack-ironic.2019-12-11.log.html#t2019-12-11T07:24:17

Change-Id: I57a0074a7f6c4495e7c73a00c87675ea87fdb6e8
Story: 2006918
Task: 37567
(cherry picked from commit 9d01756833ec97a05f301a4fa1e8b2511d7c5c74)

commit_message:
disable the use of ssh agents

This change sets allow_agent=false when
constructing the SSHTunnelForwarder to allow
execution of tests with tripleo where the agent is
not present.

Change-Id: I6534120adadcedc8feceee613e21fdbcbdf217b8

subject: Fix creation of full backup when using cindernative incremental
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-02 17:52:59.000000000', 'message': 'Fix creation of full backup when using cindernative incremental

Per configuration freezer should firstly create full backup
automatically if there are no backups for job and config options
incremental=True, mode=cindernative are set. This patch is fixing this.

From config:
>> # When the option is set, freezer will perform a cindernative
   incremental backup instead of the default full backup. And if True,
   but volume do not have a base full backup, freezer will do a full backup
   first.
>> #incremental = <None>

Change-Id: Ib56c5528bcdedc34c16c209488c7439250dd85e1
'}]
commit_message:
Fix creation of full backup when using cindernative incremental

Per configuration freezer should firstly create full backup
automatically if there are no backups for job and config options
incremental=True, mode=cindernative are set. This patch is fixing this.

From config:
>> # When the option is set, freezer will perform a cindernative
   incremental backup instead of the default full backup. And if True,
   but volume do not have a base full backup, freezer will do a full backup
   first.
>> #incremental = <None>

Change-Id: Ib56c5528bcdedc34c16c209488c7439250dd85e1

commit_message:
Randomize BaseFullStackTestCase._find_available_ips

Instead of retrieving an IP address of the CIDR network in
ascending order, this patch randomizes the IP address selection.

Change-Id: I5971d078bd68c3c0b104eea0d443511e741540c4
Related-Bug: #1808595
(cherry picked from commit 94f69ab407d081ce49fa5a93946c4cd41bf6ee89)

commit_message:
Add py27 testenv for tox.ini

Since upstream requirements is removing support of py27 but
TripleO jobs still runs on py27 and which is going to break
the deps installation.

In order to fix, we can create a seperate testenv py27
to handle that and it should not depends on upstream
constriants.

Related-Bug: #1861803
Change-Id: I61365503cc1c70644d6520f54646492359fa4e44

commit_message:
Collect additional post-run information

Since we use multinode, as well as some other... more...
exotic configuraitons in our integration scenarios as
we test "bare metal", we need to collect some extra
information in order to help troubleshoot connectivity
failures.

Change-Id: I86e385794f5f90799a6e067d6add6085a0028c59

remove the role names that use dashes.

With the addition of K2K-specific tests in the tempest plugin and a
config toggle in the plugin to disable use of the external IdP, we can

commit_message:
Add voting k2k tests

With the addition of K2K-specific tests in the tempest plugin and a
config toggle in the plugin to disable use of the external IdP, we can
safely add a voting federation job. This also fixes the devstack plugin
to install the xmlsec1 tool which is needed for K2K.

Change-Id: I9dc634e073657ff337751ec67363a57bd10e20d4
Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/689222

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-03 18:31:13.000000000', 'message': "nova-net: Remove use of legacy 'Network' object

Change I77b1cfeab3c00c6c3d7743ba51e12414806b71d2 reworked things such
that random methods in 'nova.network.api.API' weren't using the legacy
nova-network 'FloatingIP' object as a container. Now do the same for the
'Network' object, which is similarly unncessary here.

Change-Id: I62fd27856a52adc65a90ad6301a6e47928347f52
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
nova-net: Remove use of legacy 'Network' object

Change I77b1cfeab3c00c6c3d7743ba51e12414806b71d2 reworked things such
that random methods in 'nova.network.api.API' weren't using the legacy
nova-network 'FloatingIP' object as a container. Now do the same for the
'Network' object, which is similarly unncessary here.

Change-Id: I62fd27856a52adc65a90ad6301a6e47928347f52
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
[FIX] Fix nova and neutron apparmor and  gate jobs

Disabled barbican running in the apparmor job temporarily
until the correct profile gets used and it can deploy
succesfully

Change-Id: I7d27237ac625dcc686f7262619c0caa0a7d24bb7

commit_message:
Align the usage of the two extra lb vip parameters

As extra_lb_tls_vip_addresses required a default due to how it's used
I'm also adding a default for extra_lb_vip_addresses and removing the if
defined for it for clarity.

Change-Id: If217f811dab9cfa2f459f5f50bc67bcf31ddbaaa

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-31 18:17:21.000000000', 'message': 'Remove all the "container_cli rmi -f" from HA containers

Back in the days we had added the rmi -f container calls in order
to try and clean up any old unused container images whenever we updated
any HA container. Nowadays this already happens via the
tripleo_ansible/tripleo_podman/purge role which prunes any unused
container image.

There is no point in keeping this code around since we already purge
images as a post upgrade/update task. We want to remove this code also
because it fails horribly when we update the HA containers with an image
that is based off the previously deployed image. In fact that fails
with:
TASK [Remove previous galera images] *******************************************
Friday 31 January 2020  10:34:40 +0000 (0:00:02.684)       0:02:56.021 ********
fatal: [database-0]: FAILED! => {"changed": true, "cmd": "podman rmi -f 209e952aa6cb3c212e57e5f81693eb4776c0c4b6cf96fb4faabdaa7403b2a94d", "delta": "0:00:00.110460", "end": "2020-01-31 10:34:40.772522", "msg": "non-zero return code", "rc": 2, "start": "2020-01-31 10:34:40.662062", "stderr": "Error: unable to delete \"209e952aa6cb3c212e57e5f81693eb4776c0c4b6cf96fb4faabdaa7403b2a94d\" (cannot be forced) - image has dependent child images", "stderr_lines": ["Error: unable to delete \"209e952aa6cb3c212e57e5f81693eb4776c0c4b6cf96fb4faabdaa7403b2a94d\" (cannot be forced) - image has dependent child images"], "stdout": "", "stdout_lines": []}

This is particularly important because any hotfix container
generated with tripleo-modify-image role will be affected by this issue.

We tested this by doing the following:
1) Deploying an overcloud
2) Patching all HA containers with tripleo-modify-image
3) Running an update

With this change the update did not fail any longer and the correct
images were being used by pacemaker after the update process.

Co-Authored-By: Sofer Athlan-Guyot <sathlang@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I5346b32962b8cee5c64e4f07c0b68e2512085e83
Closes-Bug: #1861498
'}, {'created': '2020-02-01 09:46:55.000000000', 'message': 'Remove all the "container_cli rmi -f" from HA containers

Back in the days we had added the rmi -f container calls in order
to try and clean up any old unused container images whenever we updated
any HA container. Nowadays this already happens via the

commit_message:
Remove all the "container_cli rmi -f" from HA containers

Back in the days we had added the rmi -f container calls in order
to try and clean up any old unused container images whenever we updated
any HA container. Nowadays this already happens via the
tripleo_ansible/tripleo_podman/purge role which prunes any unused
container image.

There is no point in keeping this code around since we already purge
images as a post upgrade/update task. We want to remove this code also
because it fails horribly when we update the HA containers with an image
that is based off the previously deployed image. In fact that fails
with:
TASK [Remove previous galera images] *******************************************
Friday 31 January 2020  10:34:40 +0000 (0:00:02.684)       0:02:56.021 ********
fatal: [database-0]: FAILED! => {"changed": true, "cmd": "podman rmi -f 209e952aa6cb3c212e57e5f81693eb4776c0c4b6cf96fb4faabdaa7403b2a94d", "delta": "0:00:00.110460", "end": "2020-01-31 10:34:40.772522", "msg": "non-zero return code", "rc": 2, "start": "2020-01-31 10:34:40.662062", "stderr": "Error: unable to delete \"209e952aa6cb3c212e57e5f81693eb4776c0c4b6cf96fb4faabdaa7403b2a94d\" (cannot be forced) - image has dependent child images", "stderr_lines": ["Error: unable to delete \"209e952aa6cb3c212e57e5f81693eb4776c0c4b6cf96fb4faabdaa7403b2a94d\" (cannot be forced) - image has dependent child images"], "stdout": "", "stdout_lines": []}

This is particularly important because any hotfix container
generated with tripleo-modify-image role will be affected by this issue.

We tested this by doing the following:
1) Deploying an overcloud
2) Patching all HA containers with tripleo-modify-image
3) Running an update

With this change the update did not fail any longer and the correct
images were being used by pacemaker after the update process.

Co-Authored-By: Sofer Athlan-Guyot <sathlang@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I5346b32962b8cee5c64e4f07c0b68e2512085e83
Closes-Bug: #1861498
(cherry picked from commit 9a830255b73ec42edbdc8f7c417ebddc3ba364e4)

commit_message:
libvirt: don't call sync_guest_time if qga is not enabled

sync_guest_time relies on qga.
If we don't enable qga in image_meta, don't call it.

Closes-bug: #1738997
Change-Id: Icd7e7732db84d012e97fd912d312a1f826116269
Signed-off-by: Chen Hanxiao <chen_han_xiao@126.com>

commit_message:
Update sphinx library and treat warnings as errors

This commit updates sphinx library and treats warnings as errors. We
often miss doc warnings. So this commit makes them errors to build a
better html document.

Change-Id: I86fc23761ec24b0fdaae234cf37737dbc1bddd29

commit_message:
[ussuri][goal] Drop python 2.7 support and testing

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

Complete discussion & schedule can be found in
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010142.html
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Change-Id: I4444bfd4b729ccd86dabe1f2c37f475a3368a812

commit_message:
tox: Use python3 within tempestenv

If3ff71dbe636ef98072b15f6599e6e641c222f30 had switched this to python3.6
but this breaks on distros where 3.6 is no longer provided by default,
such as Fedora.

Closes-Bug: #1861308
Change-Id: I0e0b9e88eea2499cb1b9727a7787c050c869c819

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-29 16:38:11.000000000', 'message': 'Drop python 3.5 support from Tempest

Tempest, its plugins and their dependencies in ussuri
cycle are python-requires>=py3.6 which makes distro not
having python 3.6 to do hack to install py3.6 etc.

We cannot do >py3.6 in basepython so one way is to drop the
py3.5 support and basepython to py3 so that it can choose
the available py version in env.

It time to drop the py3.5 from Tempest. Last supported version of
    Tempest for py3.5 is 23.0.0.

Change-Id: I872dbb57df46d1193c0d409bb00d56f372d295fe
Related--Bug: 1861308
'}, {'created': '2020-01-29 17:50:14.000000000', 'message': 'Drop python 3.5 support from Tempest

having python 3.6 to do hack to install py3.6 etc.

We cannot do >py3.6 in basepython so one way is to drop the
py3.5 support and basepython to py3 so that it can choose
the available py version in env.

It time to drop the py3.5 from Tempest. Last supported version of

commit_message:
Drop python 3.5 support from Tempest

Tempest, its plugins and their dependencies in ussuri
cycle are python-requires>=py3.6 which makes distro not
having python 3.6 to do hack to install py3.6 etc.

We cannot do >py3.6 in basepython so one way is to drop the
py3.5 support and basepython to py3 so that it can choose
the available py version in env.

It time to drop the py3.5 from Tempest. Last supported version of
Tempest for py3.5 is 23.0.0.

oslo drop py2 so we need to remove the py2 unit test job which
is failing and blocking gate.

There is seoarate work to drop the py2 things from Tempest in
compplete set.

Change-Id: I872dbb57df46d1193c0d409bb00d56f372d295fe
Related-Bug: 1861308

commit_message:
Use contraints for tempest plugins

This patch unifies the master branch with the changes which have
been necessary to unbreak the stable branches in light of py2 support
being removed from tempest and its plugins.

Change-Id: I1d447933af5b668c17576a0ed985683a28fa153a
(cherry picked from commit 9de0b7a59f150f5ef7bc9f85870edbafeedcbf10)

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 6873, 'name': 'Matt Riedemann', 'email': 'mriedem.os@gmail.com', 'username': 'mriedem'}, {'_account_id': 7166, 'name': 'Sylvain Bauza', 'email': 'sbauza@redhat.com', 'username': 'sbauza'}, {'_account_id': 9008, 'name': 'VMware NSX CI', 'username': 'vmwareminesweeper', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 10118, 'name': 'IBM PowerKVM CI', 'email': 'kvmpower@linux.vnet.ibm.com', 'username': 'powerkvm', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 14384, 'name': 'Quobyte CI', 'email': 'openstack-ci-external@quobyte.com', 'username': 'quobyteci', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23498, 'name': 'IBM zVM CI', 'email': 'zvmosci@us.ibm.com', 'username': 'zvmosci'}, {'_account_id': 26515, 'name': 'Cloudbase Nova Hyper-V CI', 'email': 'nova_hyperv_ci@cloudbasesolutions.com', 'username': 'nova_hyperv_ci'}, {'_account_id': 29963, 'name': 'Intel_Zuul', 'display_name': 'Intel Corporation CI', 'email': 'intel-openstack-ci@intel.com', 'username': 'Intel_Zuul'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-12-06 17:14:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-12-06 17:20:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

I'm not sure how useful this is yet. The problem is build and resize flows in the compute manage rely on the 'retry' information coming from the filter_properties dict that is populated in and passed down from conductor. So even if we pass the RequestSpec to populate_retry, we still have to then take that request spec and convert it to the legacy filter_properties dict before passing it down to compute.

So maybe the first thing to do is change the compute manager code to get the retry information from the RequestSpec, if available, rather than the filter_properties dict so that we can eventually remove the filter_properties dict from getting passed to compute and solely rely on the RequestSpec. But before we can even do that, we really need to bump the conductor RPC API major version to 2.0 so that we can assert that the request spec passed from conductor to compute for build and resize will get passed back to conductor on reschedule, otherwise we'll lose the retry information in the request spec since conductor will build a request spec from scratch (e.g. build_request_spec method)."}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2019-12-06 17:22:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Testing completed on the zVM Driver CI system check-nova pipeline and failed.  To recheck only the zVM driver plugins, submit a comment with only  zvm: recheck in the comment.. Contact information: zvmosci@us.ibm.com. For information see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ZVMDriver.

- check-nova-master http://extbasicopstackcilog01.podc.sl.edst.ibm.com/test_logs/jenkins-check-nova-master-39892 : FAILURE in 6m 18s'}, {'account_id': 29963, 'date': '2019-12-06 17:28:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Build failed.

- pmem-tempest-plugin-filtered http://52.27.155.124/97/697697/1/check/pmem-tempest-plugin-filtered/ec7c3b4/ : FAILURE in 12m 01s'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-12-06 17:31:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Sylvain: do you agree with my assessment that we can't safely move the scheduler utils methods and callers over to using a RequestSpec instead of the legacy filter_properties dict until (1) we cut conductor RPC API 2.0 and (2) switch the computes over to using the request spec rather than filter_properties for getting retry information?"}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2019-12-06 22:24:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Build succeeded.

- nova http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/697697/1 : SUCCESS in 2h 25m 44s'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2020-02-04 19:31:16.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

Change-Id: Icf1eb4631c047dfee318d35f7e57bc7d5d6565a9

commit_message:
Support RequestSpec in populate_retry

This makes the populate_retry support either a legacy
filter_properties dict or a RequestSpec object. Now
callers of the populate_retry method can be moved over
to passing a RequestSpec and once all callers have moved
we can drop the legacy dict compat code.

Part of blueprint request-spec-use-by-compute

Change-Id: Icf1eb4631c047dfee318d35f7e57bc7d5d6565a9

commit_message:
Increase featureset020 concurrency to 4

The full tempest job is timeing out. We figure out that increasing the
concurrency makes the job pass. In some tests, increase the flavor and
keep concurrency to 3 doesn't affect the time of run. Increase the
concurrency to 4 makes the job run faster, however, increase the
concurrency to 5 make the job run slower, probably because of the lack
of resources for 5 tests running in parallel. So, 4 is the magic number.

Change-Id: I0f06f78c788b5aebf597cf5d5c025e9f6339ec39

- sets the ansible option internal_poll_interval so that we lower overall cpu
  consumption.
- sets the ssh option PreferredAuthentications so that we're only offering

commit_message:
Tune ansible configuration for better performance

This change will update our ansible configuration to ensure we're getting the best
possible performance when running ansible playbooks via mistral.

- sets the ansible option internal_poll_interval so that we lower overall cpu
  consumption.
- sets the ssh option PreferredAuthentications so that we're only offering
  pubkeys when connecting to remote hosts which, in most cases, will save us
  from attempting a PTR lookup.

Change-Id: I421183abd0982f9f57f8719d72fd2cbf2e3d4d04
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 8ab0901ad7285d18e79f9070dfffb3c5e4063277)

commit_message:
Switch from 'podman rm' to tripleo-container-rm role

Rather than use the shell module directly, we switch to using the
role so that we do things consistently.

commit_message:
Start using airship citycloud cloud

It appears that the cloud launcher has configured networking on this
cloud. Next step is to uplaod images and plan out labels. We'll start at
max-servers 0 in order to get images uploaded. Then work with cloud
provider and airship to sort out quotas and max-servers values from
there.

Change-Id: Ic2f8acb64dc23c238676729839f55d7b592e0d15

commit_message:
[Ceph Nautilus] Fix _checkPGs.py.tpl for Nautilus compatibility

The output of 'ceph pg ls-by-pool' changed format in Nautilus,
which caused the checkPGs.py script to fail in some scenarios.
This change addresses that format change and fixes Nautilus
compatibility in the script. Mimic compatibility is maintained.

Change-Id: I11d8337b548f959d0a4b58b7e8f76720a0371e73

commit_message:
Remove GlanceRegistry service from roles_data.

GlanceRegistry templates where removed completely in Stein [0].
Therefore, there is no need to keep the service inside
any customized roles_data.

This patch parses the customized roles_data passed during
the upgrade prepare step and removes the GlanceRegistry service.

[0] - I548816e3f2d8b9deed8a6f0ba3e203f84ad3d9ca

Change-Id: I7660ae3d3fa4f1da54a6737bf3e8d0daa8191aa1

commit_message:
Move apparmor to use feature gates

This change refactors the apparmor job to utilize the feature
gates system instead of relying on separate scripts.

Also disabled barbican running in the apparmor job temporarily
until the correct profile gets used and it can deploy
succesfully.

Change-Id: Iadacd214de3fdb06e4acde4433c5fa86973371d5

'}, {'created': '2020-01-03 19:16:46.000000000', 'message': 'Always have username in CADF initiator

The current initiator object for CADF notifications does not include
the username of the user who initiated the action, which leads to
issues when using an LDAP backend and not having a direct way to
map a username to a user id.

This change makes it so that the initiator object for CADF
notifications always contains the username for a user as well
as the user id. This follows along with the CADF standard
for OpenStack[0].

commit_message:
Always have username in CADF initiator

The current initiator object for CADF notifications does not include
the username of the user who initiated the action, which leads to
issues when using an LDAP backend and not having a direct way to
map a username to a user id.

This change makes it so that the initiator object for CADF
notifications always contains the username for a user as well
as the user id. This follows along with the CADF standard
for OpenStack[0].

[0] https://www.dmtf.org/sites/default/files/standards/documents/DSP2038_1.1.0.pdf#page=12

Closes-Bug: #1856904

Change-Id: I833e6e0d7792acf49f816050ad7a63e8ea4f702f

commit_message:
[ussuri][goal] Drop python 2.7 support and testing

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

Complete discussion & schedule can be found in
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010142.html
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Cleanup setup.cfg, conf.py, and tox.ini from cruft.

Change-Id: Icb08c704cb5d0d8004d0a5408822c9d53ae9c728

commit_message:
Reset timeout exception in DietTestCase when retrying

In case of fixtures.TimeoutException, DietTestCase retries the
execution of the test case (introduced in [1]). But the timeout
fixture was not reset. This can lead to a general execution timeout
if a test do not exit in a proper time.

[1] If865c4683645f9bd11f5e1b528bade0547505bfd

Related-Bug: #1843478
Partial-Bug: #1848944
Change-Id: Ib6ef58b5259ea4bf151e866f6244ff87b195b139

commit_message:
Put osc unit tests with all other unit tests

Having osc in an upper level module meant that
all osc unit tests were not being run.

We had two options: either create a new job purely
for osc unit tests or put all tests on the same module.

The latter made more sense for simplicity reasons (KISS)

Change-Id: Iabf76d8ac7ef886d736f3e30d466fe3f992287da

Virsh binary is not part of the package libvirt-daemon-kvm and it's not
installed by dependecy. So `libvirt_package` was converted to a list
and `libvirt-client` is installed additionally, which provides virsh.

Change-Id: I967fd6e20e18310b4599fa00d003d7424ed73ae5

"}]
commit_message:
Install virsh for Centos

Virsh binary is not part of the package libvirt-daemon-kvm and it's not
installed by dependecy. So `libvirt_package` was converted to a list
and `libvirt-client` is installed additionally, which provides virsh.

Change-Id: I967fd6e20e18310b4599fa00d003d7424ed73ae5
(cherry picked from commit 3e03cd19193e882c219598cfc4636e92cddb5d4d)

 > branch). A released version won't cut it. Is it something like
 > adding neutron to required_projects in .zuul.yaml?

I've asked what is the suggested way, in #openstack-requirements channel, but didn't get an answer :(

If we add neutron to required_projects in .zuul.yaml, that will work and test against latest neutron directly from the branch as far as I know.

"}, {'created': '2020-01-21 17:28:56.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Adjust version constraint of hacking

This patch solves multiple problems to fix gate:

1. Neutron constrained the version of hacking < 1.2.0, but since then
   the unit tests fails with:

ERROR: Double requirement given: hacking<1.2.0,>=1.1.0 (from -ri https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/raw/branch/master/test-requirements.txt (line 4)) (already in hacking>=1.1.0 (from -r [..]networking-powervm/test-requirements.txt (line 4)), name='hacking')

   So let's simply use the same constraint as set in neutron.

2. neutron was added to upper constraints in openstack/requirements
   stable branches (I8e95dc48b8ba2a7e16f1d34eb5ad0e87a3e96f4f), which
   causes failure due to conflict with tox targets installing neutron
   directly from git:

ERROR: Could not satisfy constraints for 'neutron': installation from path or url cannot be constrained to a version

   Most of the zuul templates used in the .zuul.yaml marks neutron as
   required project except lower-constraint job. Let's make that also
   install neutron.

Note(elod.illes): by removing editable git installation of neutron from
tox involves that tests could only be run correctly in Zuul, but cannot
run locally.

Change-Id: Ic4d97db6c947264806e5ef9e35f21f764cbecf46
(cherry picked from commit a00fc731b14bd3ef953fe4cffdc74c8e441c0e13)
"}, {'created': '2020-01-21 17:54:20.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Adapt to new global neutron upper constraint and adjust hacking version

This patch solves multiple problems to fix gate:

1. Neutron constrained the version of hacking < 1.2.0, but since then
   the unit tests fails with:

ERROR: Double requirement given: hacking<1.2.0,>=1.1.0 (from -ri https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/raw/branch/master/test-requirements.txt (line 4)) (already in hacking>=1.1.0 (from -r [..]networking-powervm/test-requirements.txt (line 4)), name='hacking')

   So let's simply use the same constraint as set in neutron.

2. neutron was added to upper constraints in openstack/requirements
   stable branches (I8e95dc48b8ba2a7e16f1d34eb5ad0e87a3e96f4f), which
   causes failure due to conflict with tox targets installing neutron
   directly from git:

ERROR: Could not satisfy constraints for 'neutron': installation from path or url cannot be constrained to a version

   Most of the zuul templates used in the .zuul.yaml marks neutron as
   required project except lower-constraint job. Let's make that also
   install neutron. Also add neutron to requirements.txt.

Note(elod.illes): by removing editable git installation of neutron from
tox and adding it to requirements.txt involves that tests in Zuul will
run against latest stable state, but locally the test will run against
latest release from stable/* of neutron. So in short: they test
different things.

Change-Id: Ic4d97db6c947264806e5ef9e35f21f764cbecf46
(cherry picked from commit a00fc731b14bd3ef953fe4cffdc74c8e441c0e13)

commit_message:
Adapt to new global neutron upper constraint and adjust hacking version

This patch solves multiple problems to fix gate:

1. Neutron constrained the version of hacking < 1.2.0, but since then
   the unit tests fails with:

ERROR: Double requirement given: hacking<1.2.0,>=1.1.0 (from -ri https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/raw/branch/master/test-requirements.txt (line 4)) (already in hacking>=1.1.0 (from -r [..]networking-powervm/test-requirements.txt (line 4)), name='hacking')

   So let's simply use the same constraint as set in neutron.

2. neutron was added to upper constraints in openstack/requirements
   stable branches (I8e95dc48b8ba2a7e16f1d34eb5ad0e87a3e96f4f), which
   causes failure due to conflict with tox targets installing neutron
   directly from git:

ERROR: Could not satisfy constraints for 'neutron': installation from path or url cannot be constrained to a version

   Most of the zuul templates used in the .zuul.yaml marks neutron as
   required project except lower-constraint job. Let's make that also
   install neutron. Also add neutron to requirements.txt.

Note(elod.illes): by removing editable git installation of neutron from
tox and adding it to requirements.txt involves that tests in Zuul will
run against latest stable state, but locally the test will run against
latest release from stable/* of neutron. So in short: they test
different things.

Change-Id: Ic4d97db6c947264806e5ef9e35f21f764cbecf46
(cherry picked from commit a00fc731b14bd3ef953fe4cffdc74c8e441c0e13)

Some modules will be enabled using set_fact based on the existence of endpoints, and others will be enabled based on the defaults/user config. Given that we can't currently write the tests for the modules we don't have installed, defaulting them to false until someone needs and can test for them would be more internally consistent, as they are then all set in the same manner."}, {'account_id': 31004, 'date': '2020-01-28 15:40:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 31004, 'date': '2020-01-28 15:58:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

commit_message:
Module config updates in ELK 7x Metricbeat template

The template for metricbeat has been updated to allow modules to be
turned off from the ansible directly. This can prevent metricbeat from
regularly throwing errors for plugins that can't connect to the required
endpoints when the aren't configured.

Change-Id: Ie03688fe5e647db2374f62b13353ce36b32fcb96

commit_message:
Add none test case to shell_args_list

As an improvement in I40e6f1c2ed71ab57d6597c086554186e233d7b94 we added
support to just return '' if the variable is None. This covers this case
with a test.

Change-Id: I61d7d4b104fb4dc895dc35b7a2460b92c6ab6e59

Waiting for CI results..although workarounds do not get executed in the CI..(maybe it's time to update our CI jobs..?)"}, {'account_id': 26343, 'date': '2020-01-29 17:15:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 26343, 'date': '2020-01-29 17:16:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 26343, 'date': '2020-02-04 09:39:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-27 17:06:13.000000000', 'message': "Add new workarounds mechanism to apply workarounds via Ansible.

The tripleo-upgrade has a workarounds logic which allows us to
apply patches or specific modifications prior and after some of
the upgrade steps. However, if these workarouds need to be applied
in the overcloud nodes, the only way to do it was via a bash script
which would iterate over the nodes and apply the patch or perform a
change on each of the nodes.

This patch adds a new workarounds field: ansible_hosts. When this
option will be present in the workaround and it will be different
than an empty string then the workaround will be aplied via Ansible in
the nodes specified in that ansible_hosts field. This ansible_hosts
option needs to be used in combination with the command one, as
the command will be transformed in a shell Ansible task which will
be executed in the nodes passed in the ansible_hosts option.

Example:
pre_overcloud_upgrade_prepare_workarounds:
- set_root_password:
    patch: false
    basedir: ''
    id: ''
    ansible_hosts: 'overcloud'
    command: |
        echo redhat | passwd root --stdin

will turn into a set_root_password.yaml Ansible playbook under
~/ansible_workarounds:

cat ~/ansible_workarounds/set_root_password.yaml
- hosts: overcloud
  tasks:
    - name: set_root_password workaround
      shell: |
        echo redhat | passwd root --stdin

When executing the workarounds, a new bash function ansible_patch
has been included which will take care of executing the generated
Ansible playbook.

Also, an optional input parameter could be passed to workarounds.sh,
when passed, it will be taken as input for the --limit option when
executing ansible-playbook. This way, we can execute a workaround
specifically in a server, instead of running it in all of them.

Change-Id: I421ebecfc5504ac2fd225de0c4fb0cbf735bbdaf
(cherry picked from commit e582d2f30473f714260c620d5c0d3807009aa797)
(cherry picked from commit b6bac90695acecb5206227836747c7ef4f7a0ce2)

commit_message:
Add new workarounds mechanism to apply workarounds via Ansible.

The tripleo-upgrade has a workarounds logic which allows us to
apply patches or specific modifications prior and after some of
the upgrade steps. However, if these workarouds need to be applied
in the overcloud nodes, the only way to do it was via a bash script
which would iterate over the nodes and apply the patch or perform a
change on each of the nodes.

This patch adds a new workarounds field: ansible_hosts. When this
option will be present in the workaround and it will be different
than an empty string then the workaround will be aplied via Ansible in
the nodes specified in that ansible_hosts field. This ansible_hosts
option needs to be used in combination with the command one, as
the command will be transformed in a shell Ansible task which will
be executed in the nodes passed in the ansible_hosts option.

Example:
pre_overcloud_upgrade_prepare_workarounds:
- set_root_password:
    patch: false
    basedir: ''
    id: ''
    ansible_hosts: 'overcloud'
    command: |
        echo redhat | passwd root --stdin

will turn into a set_root_password.yaml Ansible playbook under
~/ansible_workarounds:

cat ~/ansible_workarounds/set_root_password.yaml
- hosts: overcloud
  tasks:
    - name: set_root_password workaround
      shell: |
        echo redhat | passwd root --stdin

When executing the workarounds, a new bash function ansible_patch
has been included which will take care of executing the generated
Ansible playbook.

Also, an optional input parameter could be passed to workarounds.sh,
when passed, it will be taken as input for the --limit option when
executing ansible-playbook. This way, we can execute a workaround
specifically in a server, instead of running it in all of them.

Change-Id: I421ebecfc5504ac2fd225de0c4fb0cbf735bbdaf
(cherry picked from commit e582d2f30473f714260c620d5c0d3807009aa797)
(cherry picked from commit b6bac90695acecb5206227836747c7ef4f7a0ce2)

[{'created': '2020-01-29 20:14:28.000000000', 'message': "Support Incremental Backup Completion In RBD

Ceph RBD backend ignores the `--incremental` option when creating a
volume backup. The first backup of a given volume is always a full
backup, and each subsequent backup is always an incremental backup.
This behavior makes it impossible to remove old backups while
keeping at least one recent backup.

Since Cinder will not find the latest_backup id as parent_id if
'--incremental=False', so we can use the parent_id to ensure
whether do the full backup in rbd driver or not.

If the incremental flag '--incremental' is not specified, this
patch will always create a new full backup for rbd volume.

commit_message:
Support Incremental Backup Completion In RBD

Ceph RBD backend ignores the `--incremental` option when creating a
volume backup. The first backup of a given volume is always a full
backup, and each subsequent backup is always an incremental backup.
This behavior makes it impossible to remove old backups while
keeping at least one recent backup.

Since Cinder will not find the latest_backup id as parent_id if
'--incremental=False', so we can use the parent_id to ensure
whether do the full backup in rbd driver or not.

If the incremental flag '--incremental' is not specified, this
patch will always create a new full backup for rbd volume.

Closes-Bug: #1810270
Closes-Bug: #1790713
Co-Authored-By: Sofia Enriquez <lsofia.enriquez@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 5018727f8e18992e64c55b84f0d5b39ae7c70b32)
(cherry picked from commit 63bfbfca98ca75a0e20387506aa5bde16e39f302)

Conflicts:
	cinder/tests/unit/backup/drivers/test_backup_ceph.py

Change-Id: I87457ff128cb86a5ff99444fcb163cc97113d6b0

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 6598, 'name': 'Berezovsky Irena', 'email': 'irenab.dev@gmail.com', 'username': 'irenab'}, {'_account_id': 11600, 'name': 'Michał Dulko', 'email': 'mdulko@redhat.com', 'username': 'dulek'}, {'_account_id': 13692, 'name': 'Roman Dobosz', 'email': 'gryf73@gmail.com', 'username': 'gryf'}, {'_account_id': 14352, 'name': 'Antoni Segura Puimedon', 'email': 'celebdor@gmail.com', 'username': 'toni'}, {'_account_id': 14570, 'name': 'Ashish Billore', 'email': 'ash.billore@samsung.com', 'username': 'ashish.billore'}, {'_account_id': 14885, 'name': 'Daniel Mellado', 'email': 'dmellado@redhat.com', 'username': 'daniel-mellado'}, {'_account_id': 21041, 'name': 'Yossi Boaron', 'email': 'yossi.boaron.dev@gmail.com', 'username': 'yboaron'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23567, 'name': 'Luis Tomas Bolivar', 'email': 'ltomasbo@redhat.com', 'username': 'ltomasbo'}, {'_account_id': 24127, 'name': 'Gary Loughnane', 'email': 'gary.loughnane@intel.com', 'username': 'garyloug'}, {'_account_id': 24604, 'name': 'Danil Golov', 'email': 'd.golov@samsung.com', 'username': 'd.golov'}, {'_account_id': 25900, 'name': 'Vladimir Kuramshin', 'email': 'vladimir@kuramsh.in', 'username': 'vkuramshin'}, {'_account_id': 26292, 'name': 'Kuralamudhan Ramakrishnan', 'email': 'kuralamudhan.ramakrishnan@intel.com', 'username': 'kural'}, {'_account_id': 27032, 'name': 'Maysa de Macedo Souza', 'email': 'maysa.macedo95@gmail.com', 'username': 'maysa'}, {'_account_id': 28082, 'name': 'Yash Gupta', 'email': 'y.gupta@samsung.com', 'username': 'y.gupta'}, {'_account_id': 28396, 'name': 'Alexey Perevalov', 'email': 'alexey.perevalov@huawei.com', 'username': 'a.perevalov'}, {'_account_id': 30454, 'name': 'Yi Yang', 'email': 'yangyi01@inspur.com', 'username': 'yangyi01'}]

[{'account_id': 24127, 'date': '2018-04-06 16:01:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 24127, 'date': '2018-04-06 16:14:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 24127, 'date': '2018-04-12 12:42:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6598, 'date': '2018-04-12 13:29:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 21041, 'date': '2018-04-12 20:58:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

Hi Gary,

Thanks a lot for contributing this patch.

Before reviewing the patch, I have some questions for you just to make sure that I understand the context.

1. This patch covers the case described in slides#14,15 of https://dpdksummit.com/Archive/pdf/2017Userspace/DPDK-Userspace2017-Day2-13-DPDKUserspace%20Summit20170927.pdf
right?

1.1 We"ll have N virtio interfaces in a single VM, right?
 Part of the virtio interfaces should go in the 'normal' network stack path and some should be attached to user space (uio_pci/generic pci)   for DPDK processing, is it correct?
If the answer to the last question is True, how kuryr/cni knows to which datapath (normal network stack or DPDK)  attach each virtio/pod ?
 
1.2 Virtio interface can support interrupt or pmd  mode, right?

1.3 For avoiding a bottleneck at the host, it's better to run OVS-DPDK or VPP at the host, correct?

1.4 For wiring network traffic to/from N pods in a single VM, we"ll use the Trunk port capability, is it correct?

2. Binding CPUs to virtio interfaces
2.1 I assume that for getting better performance in the DPDK case, we should guide the user to use CPU ISOLATION and CPU pinning when spawning the VM using OpenStack/nova 

2.2 In DPDK we should assign/bind cpu's for the data path processing task.
could you please elaborate how it's done in the context of M DPDK virtio interfaces in a single VM (with X VCPU's) ?

3. Networking 
3.1 Do we plan to have a sperate OpenStack network for the accelerated data path pods ?
3.2 DPDK East-West traffic
Typical application case in K8S,  a pod from service A 'talk' to service B and not directly to one of the pods of service B.
Is this the case also for NFV East-West application?
if yes, that means that the router should also be using accelerated DP.'}, {'account_id': 24127, 'date': '2018-04-16 12:31:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi Yossi,
Thank you for your feedback so far. These are really great questions that I think will help clarify for others reviewing. I’ll do my best to answer them for you.

1. Yes, correct. Just to give you some context on these slides. My team have been working on Unified Infrastructure (containers within VMs) for some time now and our main use case is VNFs. We contributed the Kuryr nested-macvlan and then started to look into DPDK for nested pods. Around the same time we seen another team within the company, working on FDIO, had a very similar architecture for nested pods also requiring DPDK. They referred to this as Master VM. In fact all that was needed was to add Kuryr for orchestration and Master VM was almost identical to Unified Infrastructure. So, we’ve been keeping in regular sync with these guys. These slides were presented to a DPDK conference and so we very much focused on the DPDK side of our work and also called out the potential FDIO/Master VM benefits.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-0oVgcoGfhg

1.1 With this patch, Kuryr controller requests a new Virtio interface be created and attached to the VM as it is needed. The CNI driver of the patch then does the necessary binding to the DPDK driver (uio_pci_generic). This was one of the differences between Master VM and Unified Infrastructure. The Master VM guys had a vision where the VM would be spun up with all the Virtio devices already attached. We said that using Kuryr we could do this “on the fly”. I hope this answers your question. Please get back to me if not.

1.2 Yes, correct.

1.3 Yes, correct. I think regular OVS will function but there will be a bottleneck as you have said.

1.4 The way we see it, given our VNF use case, DPDK will provide the Data Plane to the VNFs. Each DPDK interface will require its own Virtio, provided by Kuryr “on the fly” as mentioned above. Then we see something like Kuryr nested-macvlan or nested-vlan-trunk providing the Control Plane to the VNFs. This depends on Kuryr supporting multiple VIFs, right now we are using Multus. Again, I hope I’ve interpreted your question correctly. I don’t see trunk port being used for the DPDK interfaces but for the Control Plane.

2.1 Yes, this is correct. In our setup our VMs are pinned and our CPUs are isolated. We are also using NUMA awareness.

2.2 In our VMs we have a 1:1 relationship between physical and virtual cores. The VM is created with X number of cores pinned. Each time a new Virtio interface is attached for the purpose of DPDK and a DPDK process is spawned, one of these cores is consumed. 

3.1 I guess this depends on the requirements of the end user. The user may just want to have the accelerated network. In our test setup we have 2 nodes right now. One node runs regular OVS and the other one runs OVS-DPDK, so VMs requiring the accelerated data path get launched on the second node. So this kind of dual network setup is also an option.

3.2 I’m not sure I understand this question, could you clarify a little?'}, {'account_id': 21041, 'date': '2018-04-16 14:00:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(3 comments)

Hi Gary,

Your answers were very helpful!
 
As per 3.2, just wanted to understand the application connecting model in case of DPDK East-West.  Since Pods are mortal, the K8S recommended approach to connect containers is using Services [1].
In that case, a Pod of service 'A' should talk to service 'B' and not directly to one of service's  'B' pods.


I have another question regarding the DPDK CNI/binding, there's one part that 'switches' the interface from VM's IP stack to DPDK (using the bind python script), where/how the DPDK interface is attached to the relevant Pod ? 

[1] https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/services-networking/connect-applications-service/

Thanks
Yossi"}, {'account_id': 24127, 'date': '2018-04-23 09:53:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 24127, 'date': '2018-04-23 09:55:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 24127, 'date': '2018-05-09 13:24:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:
