@Nikhil, I apologize for not having time to participate in every part of the discussion of this work last cycle. I thought the glance team had it well in hand and had settled on a minimal change that would provide an API meeting the needs for DefCore and users. The scope seems to have grown since that time, which is concerning because it is extremely important that this work be finished as soon as possible.

The copy-from-url case seems reasonable. I strongly encourage you to do that work after some DefCore-compatible version of the other import mechanisms is completely working and the tests are written to the DefCore team's criteria (although you shouldn't wait for them to actually adopt the tests). From a contributor community perspective getting *SOMETHING* DefCore can use is more important that deprecating any of the existing APIs which provide these "deal breaker" features. That will allow us to move ahead with the new work while maintaining support for the old APIs, deprecating them later (or even just deciding to continue to support them -- either way the decision and work is deferred).

Regarding the confusion about the plan outside of the glance team, it would help greatly with communication if someone could write a short (very very short) description of how the API will work without getting into all of the details of exactly what is in each header or part of the request or response, but explaining how the calls are different (the spec on this is long, convoluted, and difficult for someone who is not already an expert in glance to understand at this point). For example, "The client will use the discovery API to find out which upload/import mechanisms are enabled in a cloud. Then they will use the response to call the appropriate API methods to perform the upload/import the image in one of the supported ways. For method X, they will call endpoint A, providing...". Please send that to the mailing list where it is easier to have a discussion like this.

Regarding a default upload mechanism, we seem to be placing a lot of faith in security teams at different companies who all have different opinions about how uploading should work to be "safe". Rather than choosing upstream, where we don't really care as long as the feature is supported, I suggest that we just write the tests to require that one of the several mechanisms is available for uploading an image from outside of the cloud. We can have a separate test for each mechanism that "skips" if the mechanism is not actually enabled, unless *no*  mechanism is enabled in which case it should fail. If the mechanism to be tested is enabled, the test will only be handling one case so it can be written clearly without a bunch of branching. If the tests for direct, swift, and copy-from all also test that *some*  mechanism is enabled then we'll be able to ensure that all clouds provide the feature in some way without dictating what that is. The DefCore team can then figure out how to specify "one of these N tests must pass" (maybe they already have a way to do that, I don't know).'}, {'account_id': 2537, 'date': '2016-05-14 17:27:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

@Doug:

Thanks a ton for your clear cut reply! I appreciate the approach.


I echo your sentiment 100% and that is also exactly what I mean to say, in all that I am saying. We need to get things done ASAP and we can’t halt small patches just because they have TODOs on them. We need to understand why those exists say something planned ahead and ping people on irc so see why so — being super efficient in communication. Why I say that? Please see my elaborate response inline.


> @Nikhil, I apologize for not having time to participate in every part of the discussion of this work last cycle. I thought the glance team had it well in hand and had settled on a minimal change that would provide an API meeting the needs for DefCore and users. The scope seems to have grown since that time, which is concerning because it is extremely important that this work be finished as soon as possible.

Firstly, no issues Doug, I think we all do not expect you to participate in all the discussions. Also, I would not want the TC members thinking that Glance team does not have this in hand. Because, that is not really the case.

The very fact that you are saying that Glance team does not have this in hand is what is really disappointing. The entire purpose of my response was to indicate that we know what we are doing and there’s good reference provided in there to indicate that. If anything, I think anyone who is not involved in Glance on regular basis need to make an informed review, decisions, communication when they want to hold back something. Please (I request you please) do not blame this on Glance. I think we’ve had a fair share of bad publicity and to be fair none of that is our fault. All the development has been done publicly, all the API changes proposed as summit sessions and people have been provided an opportunity to provide feedback. It is really unfortunate that people have a strong say on how things should work post something is implemented or when it has been discussed on the spec and implementation is in progress.

It’s a big failure for the OpenStack community, our review mechanism isn’t either fair or efficient. Our communication on ML, emails, etherpads etc. isn’t efficient and that results in a cultural habit of the same. We need to make informed reviews and decisions, always. And if we are not sure we need to ask the right questions that will not generate more speculation. 

If you think I am proposing to slow down the proposal, then I should think I have failed miserably in communicating the intent — just to let you know I have been pushing for this to be done as a MVP  (something viable for DefCore) since Mitaka (just prior to elections, after elections & before summit, after the summit and now when I have a fair idea of how we are going to more forward on this.) Brian Rosmaita (as per his nod last week) and I are going to see this through (or I myself will see this through in Newton).  I have proposed a break down of the proposal as MVP (followed by everything else) at the summit. And to be honest, I feel the most pressure to get this done more than anyone else (due to many many reasons that people do not know).  If you think this is utter non-sense you can confirm with others (starting Brian).

In my defense, I had asked if we need to discuss this as a work session at the summit but the majority wins and it did not make it. Though I had asked people to join us for this discussion during the summit in the contributors’ meet up where the team was preferring to discuss this. Also, I have pushed back the mid-cycle to June 15-17 (quite early in the cycle) just to make sure we are on the right track to get this done. Also, I am proposing for us to have more efficient channels of communication as I am really tired of the long discussions happening time after time, late, very very late. So, no offense to anyone it’s not me who is blocking the progress.

Having said that, I think the end goal of any proposal should be that we have a successful cloud running OpenStack. When people vet their opinions that certain use cases are essential for them then I think it becomes important for us to consider them given OpenStack’s mission statement is also about building massively scalable clouds https://governance.openstack.org/resolutions/20160106-mission-amendment.html?highlight=mission . 

Having a trivial implementation is no way to move forward to support that case. Popularity of the use of the API is one aspect of implementing something, technically excellent is another end of the spectrum. We need to be empathetic about both the kind of APIs. 

I attempted my best to give a quick yet holistic response to how we need to move forward supporting both our needs going forward. It has been my experience that people are unwilling to budge after saying that is was discussed and we won’t support it. So, the copy-from case becomes important to be brought up now and people know that it is a possibility (yes only a possibility of the future but not (anything less than possibility) say probability).


> The copy-from-url case seems reasonable. I strongly encourage you to do that work after some DefCore-compatible version of the other import mechanisms is completely working and the tests are written to the DefCore team's criteria (although you shouldn't wait for them to actually adopt the tests). From a contributor community perspective getting *SOMETHING* DefCore can use is more important that deprecating any of the existing APIs which provide these "deal breaker" features. That will allow us to move ahead with the new work while maintaining support for the old APIs, deprecating them later (or even just deciding to continue to support them -- either way the decision and work is deferred).

I cannot agree more than what you are saying. I have always been in the favor of not deprecating before (new) things are implemented but that trend seems to be going otherwise in OpenStack and I strongly dislike that. We need operational convenience before making deal breakers — even if it’s supporting older APIs. So, +2 on that!

Thanks for being practical on the copy-from case, it appears to be equally popular case as the direct streaming to glance — because it’s more asynchronous thus convenient. For large scale (in terms of number of uploads or in terms of larger uploads) I think it’s more useful for a user to simply specify a url and wait for the import happens (a _more_ cloud friendly operation).

I am not encouraging the copy-from case to be implemented before/in parallel to the DefCore capabilities. You can see in the spec that I have not asked for it as a part of the first Import Refactor implementation (as we can understand that it’s about DefCore) the future discussion on how to support more can happen later. But at the same time, all the late push back on things makes is really difficult to ensure that your use cases are not heard for and people say you missed the train. That’s not the right approach we need to take — hence if a point brought up earlier then better.


> Regarding the confusion about the plan outside of the glance team, it would help greatly with communication if someone could write a short (very very short) description of how the API will work without getting into all of the details of exactly what is in each header or part of the request or response, but explaining how the calls are different (the spec on this is long, convoluted, and difficult for someone who is not already an expert in glance to understand at this point). For example, "The client will use the discovery API to find out which upload/import mechanisms are enabled in a cloud. Then they will use the response to call the appropriate API methods to perform the upload/import the image in one of the supported ways. For method X, they will call endpoint A, providing...". Please send that to the mailing list where it is easier to have a discussion like this.


I am okay with the writing the description but it’s a really sad part that we are planning to have this discussion after the spec is approved and we are at more than 7 months since this spec was first published. This has been my really worry and hence the subsequent response. I keep getting worried about the bad publicity Glance team keeps getting (for something that’s not our fault) and the headers discussion that should really have been on the spec. Besides, there are other teams that are not using glance properly and leaks exist in the system — no one is willing to look (research) that way of how disastrous our implementations exists based on bad/wrong assumptions. I had to self-assign a research task to gather facts around the same. It seems like people want to target Glance team and I really hope that is not true. How can I be sure?

We are however okay to write a wiki (heck even a spec) where the discussion could happen in a sane manner and there’s no bad intent communicated. When we are marching forward as fast as we can to get things implemented for DefCore, I hate to have another series of long ML discussions — that’s not the efficient way to communicate things (at least when there are elements who want to target Glance) as per past experience.


> Regarding a default upload mechanism, we seem to be placing a lot of faith in security teams at different companies who all have different opinions about how uploading should work to be "safe". Rather than choosing upstream, where we don't really care as long as the feature is supported, I suggest that we just write the tests to require that one of the several mechanisms is available for uploading an image from outside of the cloud. We can have a separate test for each mechanism that "skips" if the mechanism is not actually enabled, unless *no* mechanism is enabled in which case it should fail. If the mechanism to be tested is enabled, the test will only be handling one case so it can be written clearly without a bunch of branching. If the tests for direct, swift, and copy-from all also test that *some* mechanism is enabled then we'll be able to ensure that all clouds provide the feature in some way without dictating what that is. The DefCore team can then figure out how to specify "one of these N tests must pass" (maybe they already have a way to do that, I don't know).

I think that sounds fair and again I echo that sentiment. It’s a pain that there are many influencers in this effort who are not always coordinated. I have been on the same opinion that we need to pass at least one test for a particular import mechanism and if that passes then the interop branding can be given.

Again, I really want to have the most efficient communication where we are not repeating the same arguments again and that we are considering all elements of the OpenStack mission statement when implementing something ( https://governance.openstack.org/resolutions/20160106-mission-amendment.html?highlight=mission ).

I have made the mid-cycle very early in the cycle, sent out the email to ML early too, am pushing Glancers to attend the same as far as possible (even if remotely) discuss Import. I’ve come up with priorities that are not conflicting (not technically controvertial) with each other and enables different Glancers to keep themselves busy with just the right things (focus). I am encouraging other mediums of communication when appropriate and needed, expressing the intent where needed and very strongly encouraging for people to focus on MVP. I am keeping an eye on Glance ML emails and making sure we do not step ahead or step back of ourselves. 

Let me know how else I can be of assistance when it comes to communicating the right things. I am happy to do that as long as it helps us being “unstuck”.

Danke!'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2016-05-16 17:29:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

@Nikhil, I've cut quite a bit of your response. It seems I've given you the impression that I'm attacking you personally, or the Glance core team. That was not my intent, and I'm sorry for phrasing things in a way that made it seem otherwise. I know the team has been working hard on this. Although I didn't participate in all of the discussions on the spec or at the summit, I have been trying to keep up at least enough to know that the problem was still being worked on.

 > @Doug:
 > 
 > Thanks a ton for your clear cut reply! I appreciate the approach.
 > 
 > 
 > I echo your sentiment 100% and that is also exactly what I mean to
 > say, in all that I am saying. We need to get things done ASAP and
 > we can’t halt small patches just because they have TODOs on them.
 > We need to understand why those exists say something planned ahead
 > and ping people on irc so see why so — being super efficient in
 > communication. Why I say that? Please see my elaborate response
 > inline.

I think this process would go a lot more smoothly if folks wrote about their plans more clearly using fewer words. A simple comment in this patch saying something like "we'll be adding supported methods to this list explicitly as we implement them inside glance" would address the TODO question.

 > The very fact that you are saying that Glance team does not have
 > this in hand is what is really disappointing. The entire purpose of

The last time I looked at this work the scope was limited to fixing the API on top of the existing mechanisms for getting images into glance. That grew a bit with the pull API, but as I said that's fine. All of the background stuff about processing images based on the task API implementation feels a bit like overkill for an initial version, but assuming it's reusing the existing implementation it should also be fine. So what seems to not be "in hand" is the part where you communicate the plan clearly to all of the folks outside of the glance core team who have an interest in the outcome, and to ensure that the API is generally suitable for the new requirements that led to creating it. Has someone done that review?

 > my response was to indicate that we know what we are doing and
 > there’s good reference provided in there to indicate that. If
 > anything, I think anyone who is not involved in Glance on regular
 > basis need to make an informed review, decisions, communication
 > when they want to hold back something. Please (I request you
 > please) do not blame this on Glance. I think we’ve had a fair share
 > of bad publicity and to be fair none of that is our fault. All the
 > development has been done publicly, all the API changes proposed as
 > summit sessions and people have been provided an opportunity to
 > provide feedback. It is really unfortunate that people have a
 > strong say on how things should work post something is implemented
 > or when it has been discussed on the spec and implementation is in
 > progress.

We are all trying to help build a robust solution that meets all of the requirements. If folks have concerns about the suitability of the proposed API, and whether it is going to meet the DefCore needs that triggered this work in the beginning, having that feedback now is better than after code is in glance. Even if it seems late because of the length of time the glance team has been discussing the issue, not everyone was involved in those team discussions.

 > just to let you know I have been pushing for this to be done as a
 > MVP  (something viable for DefCore) since Mitaka (just prior to
 > elections, after elections & before summit, after the summit and
 > now when I have a fair idea of how we are going to more forward on
 > this.) Brian Rosmaita (as per his nod last week) and I are going to
 > see this through (or I myself will see this through in Newton).  I

I'm glad to know it is a high priority for several members of the team to make progress on this work. 

 > In my defense, I had asked if we need to discuss this as a work
 > session at the summit but the majority wins and it did not make it.
 > Though I had asked people to join us for this discussion during the
 > summit in the contributors’ meet up where the team was preferring
 > to discuss this. Also, I have pushed back the mid-cycle to June
 > 15-17 (quite early in the cycle) just to make sure we are on the
 > right track to get this done. Also, I am proposing for us to have
 > more efficient channels of communication as I am really tired of
 > the long discussions happening time after time, late, very very
 > late. So, no offense to anyone it’s not me who is blocking the
 > progress.

This is a big change. You should expect lots of discussion. I'm not really any happier than you are that further discussion will mean further delays, but if we end up with an API that doesn't do what we need then rushing to finish it won't really have saved us any time.

 > 
 > Having said that, I think the end goal of any proposal should be
 > that we have a successful cloud running OpenStack. When people vet
 > their opinions that certain use cases are essential for them then I
 > think it becomes important for us to consider them given
 > OpenStack’s mission statement is also about building massively
 > scalable clouds https://governance.openstack.org/resolutions/20160106-mission-amendment.html?highlight=mission
 > .
 > 
 > Having a trivial implementation is no way to move forward to
 > support that case. Popularity of the use of the API is one aspect
 > of implementing something, technically excellent is another end of
 > the spectrum. We need to be empathetic about both the kind of APIs.

I'm not sure where you got "trivial" from. What I have been anticipating is a new API that sits in front of a bunch of existing features of Glance for which the API is either exposed poorly or not at all. Because I'm not intimately familiar with the existing glance code and feature set, I can't tell if that's what's being built, though, or if there are a bunch of new features being added in at the same time.

 > I attempted my best to give a quick yet holistic response to how we
 > need to move forward supporting both our needs going forward. It
 > has been my experience that people are unwilling to budge after
 > saying that is was discussed and we won’t support it. So, the
 > copy-from case becomes important to be brought up now and people
 > know that it is a possibility (yes only a possibility of the future
 > but not (anything less than possibility) say probability).

Perhaps if there was some sort of documentation for the implementation phases that would help everyone.

 > I am not encouraging the copy-from case to be implemented before/in
 > parallel to the DefCore capabilities. You can see in the spec that
 > I have not asked for it as a part of the first Import Refactor
 > implementation (as we can understand that it’s about DefCore) the

The spec at http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/glance-specs/specs/mitaka/approved/image-import/image-import-refactor.html only mentions copy-from in passing. Is it in another spec somewhere else?

 > We are however okay to write a wiki (heck even a spec) where the
 > discussion could happen in a sane manner and there’s no bad intent
 > communicated. When we are marching forward as fast as we can to get
 > things implemented for DefCore, I hate to have another series of
 > long ML discussions — that’s not the efficient way to communicate
 > things (at least when there are elements who want to target Glance)
 > as per past experience.

Like it or not, the mailing list is our most effective asynchronous discussion forum.'}, {'account_id': 2537, 'date': '2016-05-17 05:11:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

@Doug:





> It seems I've given you the impression that I'm attacking you personally, or the Glance core team. That was not my intent, and I'm sorry for phrasing things in a way that made it seem otherwise. I know the team has been working hard on this. Although I didn't participate in all of the discussions on the spec or at the summit, I have been trying to keep up at least enough to know that the problem was still being worked on.






I wasn’t referring to any specific individual attacking the Glance team. It has been our experience that any thread on ML results into a diversion that doesn’t give us the fruitful response required for us to move forward and it creates bad press for Glance. The team overall is unhappy with this and I’ve been given this feedback at the summit. Again, I do intend to say that you or any one specific is targeting us, but there are elements on the ML that results into such situation.






> I think this process would go a lot more smoothly if folks wrote about their plans more clearly using fewer words. A simple comment in this patch saying something like "we'll be adding supported methods to this list explicitly as we implement them inside glance" would address the TODO question.






Surely, we will work on the documentation more. To be frank, the spec is the most convenient document and we were hoping for it to be something worth referring to or for asking questions if there are doubt on specific elements of it. But we take your feedback that we need to simplify further and I think that can be done. However, at the end of the day we work with people and the most accurate understanding can only come by talking to people.







> The last time I looked at this work the scope was limited to fixing the API on top of the existing mechanisms for getting images into glance. That grew a bit with the pull API, but as I said that's fine. All of the background stuff about processing images based on the task API implementation feels a bit like overkill for an initial version, but assuming it's reusing the existing implementation it should also be fine. So what seems to not be "in hand" is the part where you communicate the plan clearly to all of the folks outside of the glance core team who have an interest in the outcome, and to ensure that the API is generally suitable for the new requirements that led to creating it. Has someone done that review?







I do not think we are working on anything that involves task API at the moment. The end user facing API is pretty clean as you can see from the spec, there is no magic and it clearly states all the calls that need to be made to successfully import an image including the request body, response and the schema changes. So, the way Glance team think is that the spec clearly explains the approach we are taking with the API. We are hoping that people will read the spec and ask questions on the spec if something isn’t clear or needs to be added before jumping to conclusions (something I hope isn’t happening). I really want all those who are worried about this API to be involved in the syncs, and we will use non-glance language to ensure people can collaborate easily. We have made good attempts of keeping the community open friendly and easy to talk to but despite that we see delays in the involvement and apprehension to contribute early on.







> We are all trying to help build a robust solution that meets all of the requirements. If folks have concerns about the suitability of the proposed API, and whether it is going to meet the DefCore needs that triggered this work in the beginning, having that feedback now is better than after code is in glance. Even if it seems late because of the length of time the glance team has been discussing the issue, not everyone was involved in those team discussions.






I think it’s a bad assumption that what Glance team is discussing is significantly different from what DefCore requirements are. We all are trying to develop something that is going to play well with all concerned without making it interop hostile. So, I do welcome everyone in the discussions and the Glance only discussions can be done separately so that we are not wasting people’s time.





> I'm glad to know it is a high priority for several members of the team to make progress on this work. 





Thank you.





> This is a big change. You should expect lots of discussion. I'm not really any happier than you are that further discussion will mean further delays, but if we end up with an API that doesn't do what we need then rushing to finish it won't really have saved us any time.






I agree and it’s good to have further discussions. But I’m trying to make sure that we do not repeat the same arguments. You can only imagine the disappointment from Glance team if argue the same things over and over again.







> I'm not sure where you got "trivial" from. What I have been anticipating is a new API that sits in front of a bunch of existing features of Glance for which the API is either exposed poorly or not at all. Because I'm not intimately familiar with the existing glance code and feature set, I can't tell if that's what's being built, though, or if there are a bunch of new features being added in at the same time.





I think that’s my bad — a poor choice of words when saying “trivial”. The streaming part of the call or putting data directly onto the glance node is something that’s not massively scalable. So, let’s scratch that off for now as it’s a implementation detail that I inadvertently mentioned. I think the spec is a good source of truth on what we are planning to build and if someone points out that what we are doing is not in the spec, that will be more than helpful feedback. We are working hard on updating the spec as we get feedback — you can imaging that’s only natural with the kind & length of change this is.






> Perhaps if there was some sort of documentation for the implementation phases that would help everyone.





Thanks for that feedback, it is helpful to prioritize it. It becomes relevant when people ask for it — you can see that Glance team is short on the head count on the number of people fully involved in this spec/work so we are optimally working on the most required changes. We are, however, looking for and very appreciative of the constructive feedback given. So, a very special thank you.




 
> The spec at http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/glance-specs/specs/mitaka/approved/image-import/image-import-refactor.html only mentions copy-from in passing. Is it in another spec somewhere else?





I guess we could add more info. Like I said, the Glance team wants to be precise on the initial phase of the implementation. I guess we could add more information on the possible future changes — something team wanted to avoid specifically as it would create confusion. Unfortunately, missing info has created confusion!





> Like it or not, the mailing list is our most effective asynchronous discussion forum.





I do like ML when they make sense. As you can see that people are not afraid to troll on the lists and make irrelevant points that lead to a very disruptive behavior and delay in making changes — even it affects the ability to fully resolve a particular issue. If you think, it is still a good idea, I am willing to put faith in your words.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2016-05-19 12:46:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

Following up on a suggestion from Doug, I've put together a quick Image Import FAQ to give people a quick entry point into the spec to make it easy to understand the overall design so that people can make more informed comments about how particular implementation pieces, such as this very patch we're commenting on, fit into the total scheme.

Image Import FAQ patch: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/318313/"}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2016-05-21 14:23:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

commit_message:
Image Import Refactor: Value discovery

This commit introduces a new 'v2/info/import' resource for value
discovery during the image import process.

The approved spec and associated details related to this call are at
http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/glance-specs/specs/mitaka/approved/image-import/image-import-refactor.html#value-discovery

Co-Authored-By: Cyril Roelandt <cyril@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Nikhil Komawar <nik.komawar@gmail.com>

* TODO: improve the commit message
* TODO: add release notes
* TODO: add details why config is not auto refreshed here
* TODO: add explanation of why the call is setup this way and tested

Change-Id: If5bb4b608d02c502e2cec953317c9156865e58de
Partially-blueprint: image-import-refactor
Partial-Bug: #1523944

[{'created': '2020-01-13 11:45:58.000000000', 'message': '[OVN] Migrate the OVN tools

This patch is migrating the OVN tools and adding its entry points.

Change-Id: Ia1575b2b7fb93b09d8e54f9230ea2f29c1d59c42
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>

[{'created': '2019-12-18 15:03:18.000000000', 'message': "Add functional recreate test for bug 1829479 and bug 1817833

Change I7b8622b178d5043ed1556d7bdceaf60f47e5ac80 started deleting
the associated resource provider when a compute service is deleted.
However, the delete_resource_provider cascade=True logic only looks
for instances on the given compute service host being deleted which
will miss (1) allocations remaining from evacuated servers and
(2) unconfirmed migrations.

Attempting to delete the resource provider results in an
ResourceProviderInUse error which delete_resource_provider ignores
for legacy reasons. This results in the compute service being
deleted but the resource provider being orphaned. What's more,
attempting to restart the now-deleted compute service will fail
because nova-compute will try to create a new resource provider
with a new uuid but with the same name (based on the hypervisor
hostname). That failure is actually reported in bug 1817833.

Conflicts:
      nova/tests/functional/integrated_helpers.py

NOTE(mriedem): The conflict is due to not having change
Iea283322124cb35fc0bc6d25f35548621e8c8c2f in Queens so the
change to ProviderUsageBaseTestCase is made in test_servers.py
rather than integrated_helpers.py.

Change-Id: I69f52f1282c8361c9cdf90a523f3612139cb8423
Related-Bug: #1829479
Related-Bug: #1817833
(cherry picked from commit 2629d65fbc15d8698f98117e0d6072810f70da03)

commit_message:
Add functional recreate test for bug 1829479 and bug 1817833

Change I7b8622b178d5043ed1556d7bdceaf60f47e5ac80 started deleting
the associated resource provider when a compute service is deleted.
However, the delete_resource_provider cascade=True logic only looks
for instances on the given compute service host being deleted which
will miss (1) allocations remaining from evacuated servers and
(2) unconfirmed migrations.

Attempting to delete the resource provider results in an
ResourceProviderInUse error which delete_resource_provider ignores
for legacy reasons. This results in the compute service being
deleted but the resource provider being orphaned. What's more,
attempting to restart the now-deleted compute service will fail
because nova-compute will try to create a new resource provider
with a new uuid but with the same name (based on the hypervisor
hostname). That failure is actually reported in bug 1817833.

Conflicts:
      nova/tests/functional/integrated_helpers.py

NOTE(mriedem): The conflict is due to not having change
Iea283322124cb35fc0bc6d25f35548621e8c8c2f in Queens so the
change to ProviderUsageBaseTestCase is made in test_servers.py
rather than integrated_helpers.py.

Change-Id: I69f52f1282c8361c9cdf90a523f3612139cb8423
Related-Bug: #1829479
Related-Bug: #1817833
(cherry picked from commit 2629d65fbc15d8698f98117e0d6072810f70da03)
(cherry picked from commit b18e42d20bd7d341e713292bdb179ae8e5530d33)
(cherry picked from commit 6eda7409fff75449c97843b2d6ead0b3267a1099)

[{'created': '2020-02-03 12:24:06.000000000', 'message': 'Run only one ovs-vsctl in setup_vxlan_network

In CI we can see some Errors in the grenade-multinode-multitenant job:
"ovs-vsctl: Error detected while setting up 'phy-brbm-infra': could not
open network device phy-brbm-infra (No such device).  See ovs-vswitchd
log for details."

This commit changes the setup_vxlan_netwrok function to run
only one ovs-vsctl that will do everything, avoiding Errors.

Change-Id: Ib99beae77a3002146c734ab020302822c989eb12
'}]
commit_message:
Run only one ovs-vsctl in setup_vxlan_network

In CI we can see some Errors in the grenade-multinode-multitenant job:
"ovs-vsctl: Error detected while setting up 'phy-brbm-infra': could not
open network device phy-brbm-infra (No such device).  See ovs-vswitchd
log for details."

This commit changes the setup_vxlan_netwrok function to run
only one ovs-vsctl that will do everything, avoiding Errors.

Change-Id: Ib99beae77a3002146c734ab020302822c989eb12

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-31 10:34:56.000000000', 'message': 'Improve "OVSFirewallDriver.process_trusted_ports"

FirewallDriver.process_trusted_ports" is called with many ports,
"_initialize_egress_no_port_security" retrieves the VIF ports
("Interface" registers in OVS DB), one per iteration, based in the
port_id. Instead of this procedure, if the DB is called only once to
retrieve all the VIF ports, the performance increase is noticeable.
E.g.: bridge with 1000 ports and interfaces.

Retrieving 100 ports:
- Bulk operation: 0.08 secs
- Loop operation: 5.6 secs

Retrieving 1000 ports:
- Bulk operation: 0.08 secs
- Loop operation: 59 secs

Closes-Bug: #1836095
Related-Bug: #1836023

Change-Id: I5b259717c0fdb8991f1df86b1ef4fb8ad0f18e70
(cherry picked from commit ae1d36fa9d8e2115a5241b5da2e941cdefa2c463)
'}]
commit_message:
Improve "OVSFirewallDriver.process_trusted_ports"

FirewallDriver.process_trusted_ports" is called with many ports,
"_initialize_egress_no_port_security" retrieves the VIF ports
("Interface" registers in OVS DB), one per iteration, based in the
port_id. Instead of this procedure, if the DB is called only once to
retrieve all the VIF ports, the performance increase is noticeable.
E.g.: bridge with 1000 ports and interfaces.

Retrieving 100 ports:
- Bulk operation: 0.08 secs
- Loop operation: 5.6 secs

Retrieving 1000 ports:
- Bulk operation: 0.08 secs
- Loop operation: 59 secs

Closes-Bug: #1836095
Related-Bug: #1836023

Change-Id: I5b259717c0fdb8991f1df86b1ef4fb8ad0f18e70
(cherry picked from commit ae1d36fa9d8e2115a5241b5da2e941cdefa2c463)

Issue was on overcloud-controller-0 node not being able to reach the default GW at 10.0.0.1 and validation ping check failed:

Trying to ping default gateway 10.0.0.1...Ping to 10.0.0.1 failed. Retrying...

Ping to 10.0.0.1 failed. Retrying...
FAILURE
10.0.0.1 is not pingable.

But vlan10 looks to be configured correct:
10: vlan10: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 1500 qdisc noqueue state UNKNOWN group default qlen 1000
    inet 10.0.0.102/24 brd 10.0.0.255 scope global vlan10
       valid_lft forever preferred_lft forever

### IPv4 routing
default via 10.0.0.1 dev vlan10 
10.0.0.0/24 dev vlan10 proto kernel scope link src 10.0.0.102 

From checking e.g. tripleo-ci-centos-7-ovb-3ctlr_1comp-featureset001-stein-branch job, we should not use vlans? [1]

So we probably use a wrong network type as featureset001 uses "multiple-nics" [2]

commit_message:
Add nova cellv2 multicell support

This introduce needed changes to be able to deploy an additional
cell via oooq. If additional_cell is set to true after the
overcloud got deployed the additional cell gets deployed. Todo
this information gets extracted from the overcloud stack, which
is requried as input to the second heat stack, where the additional
cell is managed with. As a reference [1] is the scenario which
is installed adding a single additional cell.

config/general_config/featureset063.yml is used for the configuration
and config/nodes/1ctlr_1cellctrl_1comp.yml has a nova config
example.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/tripleo-docs/latest/features/deploy_cellv2_basic.html

Change-Id: Ib30a83f4a0bc3e503b422f8b5098c60133614959

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-31 18:12:34.000000000', 'message': 'Remove all the "container_cli rmi -f" from HA containers

Back in the days we had added the rmi -f container calls in order
to try and clean up any old unused container images whenever we updated
any HA container. Nowadays this already happens via the
tripleo_ansible/tripleo_podman/purge role which prunes any unused
container image.

There is no point in keeping this code around since we already purge
images as a post upgrade/update task. We want to remove this code also
because it fails horribly when we update the HA containers with an image
that is based off the previously deployed image. In fact that fails
with:
TASK [Remove previous galera images] *******************************************
Friday 31 January 2020  10:34:40 +0000 (0:00:02.684)       0:02:56.021 ********
fatal: [database-0]: FAILED! => {"changed": true, "cmd": "podman rmi -f 209e952aa6cb3c212e57e5f81693eb4776c0c4b6cf96fb4faabdaa7403b2a94d", "delta": "0:00:00.110460", "end": "2020-01-31 10:34:40.772522", "msg": "non-zero return code", "rc": 2, "start": "2020-01-31 10:34:40.662062", "stderr": "Error: unable to delete \"209e952aa6cb3c212e57e5f81693eb4776c0c4b6cf96fb4faabdaa7403b2a94d\" (cannot be forced) - image has dependent child images", "stderr_lines": ["Error: unable to delete \"209e952aa6cb3c212e57e5f81693eb4776c0c4b6cf96fb4faabdaa7403b2a94d\" (cannot be forced) - image has dependent child images"], "stdout": "", "stdout_lines": []}

This is particularly important because any hotfix container
generated with tripleo-modify-image role will be affected by this issue.

We tested this by doing the following:
1) Deploying an overcloud
2) Patching all HA containers with tripleo-modify-image
3) Running an update

With this change the update did not fail any longer and the correct
images were being used by pacemaker after the update process.

Co-Authored-By: Sofer Athlan-Guyot <sathlang@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I5346b32962b8cee5c64e4f07c0b68e2512085e83
Closes-Bug: #1861498
'}]
commit_message:
Remove all the "container_cli rmi -f" from HA containers

Back in the days we had added the rmi -f container calls in order
to try and clean up any old unused container images whenever we updated
any HA container. Nowadays this already happens via the
tripleo_ansible/tripleo_podman/purge role which prunes any unused
container image.

There is no point in keeping this code around since we already purge
images as a post upgrade/update task. We want to remove this code also
because it fails horribly when we update the HA containers with an image
that is based off the previously deployed image. In fact that fails
with:
TASK [Remove previous galera images] *******************************************
Friday 31 January 2020  10:34:40 +0000 (0:00:02.684)       0:02:56.021 ********

This is particularly important because any hotfix container
generated with tripleo-modify-image role will be affected by this issue.

We tested this by doing the following:
1) Deploying an overcloud
2) Patching all HA containers with tripleo-modify-image
3) Running an update

With this change the update did not fail any longer and the correct
images were being used by pacemaker after the update process.

commit_message:
Drop python 2.7 support and testing

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Include small cleanups:
* remove install_command from tox.ini, this is the default
* Use sphinx-build as modern way to run sphinx, remove setup.cfg
  settings for build-sphinx
* Use sphinxcontrib-apidoc for docs with newer sphinx
* Remove obsolete doc/source/conf.py broken
* Add python-requires to setup.cfg to make Python 3.6 requirement
  explicit
* Remove obsolete pbr setup-hooks

Co-Authored-By: Andreas Jaeger <aj@suse.com>
Change-Id: Iec8c47b82022b616b8361651bf23f853b0ce5624

messages:
[{'account_id': 31572, 'date': '2020-02-03 17:00:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2020-02-03 17:00:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 31572, 'date': '2020-02-03 17:05:36.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

[{'created': '2020-02-03 12:23:13.000000000', 'message': 'Run only one ovs-vsctl in setup_vxlan_network

In CI we can see some Errors in the grenade-multinode-multitenant job:
"ovs-vsctl: Error detected while setting up 'phy-brbm-infra': could not
open network device phy-brbm-infra (No such device).  See ovs-vswitchd
log for details."

This commit changes the setup_vxlan_netwrok function to run
only one ovs-vsctl that will do everything, avoiding Errors.

Change-Id: Ib99beae77a3002146c734ab020302822c989eb12
'}]
commit_message:
Run only one ovs-vsctl in setup_vxlan_network

In CI we can see some Errors in the grenade-multinode-multitenant job:
"ovs-vsctl: Error detected while setting up 'phy-brbm-infra': could not
open network device phy-brbm-infra (No such device).  See ovs-vswitchd
log for details."

This commit changes the setup_vxlan_netwrok function to run
only one ovs-vsctl that will do everything, avoiding Errors.

Change-Id: Ib99beae77a3002146c734ab020302822c989eb12

commit_message:
[ussuri][goal] Drop python 2.7 support and testing

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

Complete discussion & schedule can be found in
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010142.html
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Switch to modern sphinx-build and using openstackdocstheme
(note that repo is not building and publishing docs, docs building works
locally with these changes).

Change-Id: I9542c1dba3f339c2acece83d7d2b5726c1c3e2bc

commit_message:
Fix charms.ceph mocks to not depend on system version

The charms.ceph utils.py library defines a constant based
on the running OS version. This change updates where the
version is read, allowing it to be nicely mocked.

Change-Id: Ibd65526cad0812f93963bd82619fcd27e055f6f3

commit_message:
[ussuri][goal] Drop python 2.7 support

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

Update and cleanup requrirements.

Change to use openstackdocstheme, oslosphinx does not work with Python
3.
Fix redirect.py for newer sphinx versions, app.builder.info does not
exist anymore.

Remove py27 testing, we'll add py36 testing in followup with fixes for
problems found.

Use modern sphinx-build for building.

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Co-Authored-By: Andreas Jaeger <aj@suse.com>
Change-Id: Ib467fca6f9033fc331c153ba52a7a292057bb75c

subject: [k8s] Fix volumes availability zone issue
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-15 23:41:52.000000000', 'message': "[k8s] Fix volumes availability zone issue

For a multi AZ env, if Nova doesn't support cross AZ volume mount,
then the cluster creation may fail because of block device mapping
error. The patch fixes this issue by passing in the AZ information
when creating volumes for etcd, docker and the node root disk.

Task: 38131
Story: 2007097

Change-Id: I39c99259abc84cbbee50ac1a827e9349ede6593c
"}]
commit_message:
[k8s] Fix volumes availability zone issue

For a multi AZ env, if Nova doesn't support cross AZ volume mount,
then the cluster creation may fail because of block device mapping
error. The patch fixes this issue by passing in the AZ information
when creating volumes for etcd, docker and the node root disk.

Task: 38131
Story: 2007097

Change-Id: I39c99259abc84cbbee50ac1a827e9349ede6593c

commit_message:
Fix proxy for Grafana script

The prometheus/grafana script needs to download a grafana json
file by curl which doesn't work since the proxy issue. This patch
fixes it.

Task: 38167
Story: 2007005

Change-Id: I51ba108e23524eecc04bbbd47a5b50b8d4a529f9

commit_message:
[ussuri][goal] Drop python 2.7 support and testing

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

Complete discussion & schedule can be found in
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010142.html
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Change-Id: Ie8e737cfde8b2587ef60cd25ab746e6b04936390

commit_message:
Revert "Remove panko"

Panko removal had to be reverted as CF integration work was not completed
on time for train compatibility.

This reverts commit 2241528f4fd154e1f64bdeb0748c07c810ee8314.

Depends-On: Id7a1989d0a41d1563e3656dd6363ea1101a67139
Change-Id: Ide7aff1d41ae8df35035db944b8e8c28aa645a5c
Signed-off-by: Ryan McCabe <rmccabe@redhat.com>

commit_message:
tests: Nuke OS_STDOUT_CAPTURE, OS_STDERR_CAPTURE

Terminology courtesy of sdague. Turns out we can't actually use these if
we want to be able to rely on the 'self.stdout' and 'self.stderr'
properties in tests. Other people have probably discovered this already
owing to the amount of (otherwise unnecessary) mocking of stdout and
stderr going on in the tests. A future change will remove those
unnecessary mocks in favor of this centralized one.

Change-Id: I70a93bf564379d550fddaee568de4464e795a11d
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-27 10:21:41.000000000', 'message': "tests: Start using global stdout, stderr buffers

We do this for logging already. Time to start doing it for stdout and
stderr. Note that we need to pass '--suppress-attachments' to stestr
since the default behavior there is to print everything to output
regardless of whether the test failed or passed. With this flag, it's
only dumped if it failed.

Change-Id: I478f7f37087557b5385674f62c552a1b42090a37
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
tests: Start using global stdout, stderr buffers

We do this for logging already. Time to start doing it for stdout and
stderr. Note that we need to pass '--suppress-attachments' to stestr
since the default behavior there is to print everything to output
regardless of whether the test failed or passed. With this flag, it's
only dumped if it failed.

Change-Id: I478f7f37087557b5385674f62c552a1b42090a37
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Use os_tempest flipswitch from fs052

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/698211/ moves featureset overrides
to featureset 052 and stein validate-tempest is used not os_tempest
as recent update to ansible-2.9 requires latest openstacksdk version
which is not available in stable/stein uc requirements branch.

So reusing the condition from fs052 fixes the issue.

Closes-Bug: #1860810

Change-Id: I46a5a010c18583ce21182fa4e3134dd41b2fa33a
Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar (raukadah) <chkumar@redhat.com>

subject: Handle network/router delete
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 2888, 'name': 'Mathieu Rohon', 'email': 'mathieu.rohon@gmail.com', 'username': 'mathieu-rohon'}, {'_account_id': 8313, 'name': 'Lajos Katona', 'email': 'katonalala@gmail.com', 'username': 'elajkat'}, {'_account_id': 9361, 'name': 'Vivekanandan Narasimhan', 'email': 'n.vivekanandan@ericsson.com', 'username': 'viveknarasimhan'}, {'_account_id': 12021, 'name': 'Thomas Morin', 'email': 'tmmorin.orange@gmail.com', 'username': 'tmorin'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 25171, 'name': 'Deepthi V V', 'email': 'deepthi.v.v@ericsson.com', 'username': 'deepthivv88'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 25171, 'date': '2018-03-22 11:25:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 12021, 'date': '2018-03-22 14:41:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I think that this behavior (cascading a network delete into a BGPVPN network association cleanup, same for routers, ports, etc.) does not belong to plugin.py and that it should be done by each driver depending on its internal design.

The reasons are the following:
- it is not needed for all drivers (the ref driver has no need for DB sync and the existing MySQL cascading is sufficient)
- for some drivers/backends may implement the cascading internally (eg. OpenDaylight could specify in its internal datamodel that the cleanup is automatic, just like the SQL DB does)

My suggestion would be to have this behavior implemented as a helper that a driver can inherit from.'}, {'account_id': 9361, 'date': '2018-03-22 16:26:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thomas,

I tend to slightly disagree with the opinion here..

An association is a first class operation in the BGPVPN API and an associated resource to a bgpvpn is being removed from under the carpet through non-obvious deletion cascade at the DB level.  

For association we seem to enforce stronger resource coupling but however we seem to state that a disassociation is not necessary when the parent resource is deleted.

The actual workflow should insist disassociation of routers/networks from the BGPVPN first before deleting such resources when BGPVPN is still referencing them.  

The is the reason we think this should be at the API level and not at the driver level.'}, {'account_id': 9361, 'date': '2018-03-22 17:04:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 25171, 'date': '2018-03-23 10:07:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> (1 comment)

Vivek, confirmed that for this change, with V2 driver, journal db is in sync with neutron db.'}, {'account_id': 9361, 'date': '2018-03-23 11:11:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 25171, 'date': '2018-03-23 11:33:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(5 comments)'}, {'account_id': 25171, 'date': '2018-03-23 11:34:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 9361, 'date': '2018-03-23 11:59:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 25171, 'date': '2018-03-26 05:53:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 25171, 'date': '2018-03-26 06:34:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 9361, 'date': '2018-03-27 05:17:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 9361, 'date': '2018-03-27 05:18:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

Hi Thomas,

Can you please review this one?  Thanks in advance.

Vivek'}, {'account_id': 25171, 'date': '2018-03-27 06:12:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 12021, 'date': '2018-03-27 12:00:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Deepthi, Vivek --
I've given some more thought about this, and I end up seeing why it is good to have the framework provider driver hooks that are triggered whenever an association is removed because the associated network/router/port has been removed.

I'm not sure to have time to review the change today, but its on my list."}, {'account_id': 12021, 'date': '2018-03-28 13:54:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 25171, 'date': '2018-03-29 05:02:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 12021, 'date': '2018-03-29 09:24:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 12021, 'date': '2018-04-13 15:00:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Perhaps we could use the callback priority mechanism introduced recently in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/541766 . We would use PRECOMMIT, but with an infinite priority. This gets use closer to ensuring we don't run before any PRECOMMIT callback that might Abort.

More work would be needed in neutron-lib to define an 'infinite' priority and we could think about extending the priority mechanism so that a priority of infinite also means "don't abort if the callback raise an Exception".

(just thinking out loud)'}, {'account_id': 12021, 'date': '2018-08-31 15:41:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I would like to address this item.

I've just filled in bug 1790175 which describes the effect in the ML2 OVS/linuxbridge refernce driver.

Vivek, Deepthi, I'll try to find some time to address that. Ping me if you plan to work on it, so that we can coordinate."}, {'account_id': 8313, 'date': '2019-11-22 14:41:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> Perhaps we could use the callback priority mechanism introduced
 > recently in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/541766 . We would use
 > PRECOMMIT, but with an infinite priority. This gets use closer to
 > ensuring we don't run before any PRECOMMIT callback that might
 > Abort.
 > 
 > More work would be needed in neutron-lib to define an 'infinite'
 > priority and we could think about extending the priority mechanism
 > so that a priority of infinite also means "don't abort if the
 > callback raise an Exception".
 > 
 > (just thinking out loud)

Thomas: as I see no need for waiting some nuetron-lib change, see this one as an example: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/679483/5/neutron/plugins/ml2/plugin.py
Of course adding a priority is not a final solution, as it can happen that 2 plugin has priority=0 handler....'}, {'account_id': 12021, 'date': '2019-11-25 19:47:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> Patch Set 4:
 > 
 > Thomas: as I see no need for waiting some nuetron-lib change, see this one as an example: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/679483/5/neutron/plugins/ml2/plugin.py
 > Of course adding a priority is not a final solution, as it can happen that 2 plugin has priority=0 handler....

Agreed, let's be pragmatic on this one."}, {'account_id': 8313, 'date': '2020-02-03 15:10:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Hi do you plan to continue work on this?'}]

commit_message:
Handle network/router delete

On deletion of Network and Router neutron resource, which could be in
valid associations with existing BGPVPNs, we need to explicitly trigger
disassociation of themselves from all such BGPVPNs.

Change-Id: I988c22a2b99b490facfd9de12ac963c625e5a308

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-08 18:28:10.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Ensure 'HostState.numa_topology' is always an object

The 'HostState.update' function is called by
'HostManager._get_computes_for_cells' with a 'ComputeNode' object as its
first argument. The 'HostState.numa_topology' attribute is set to the
value of the 'numa_topology' attribute for this 'ComputeNode' object.
However, for legacy reasons, the 'ComputeNode.numa_topology' attribute
is currently a string representation of a 'NUMATopology' object, which
must then be converted into a real object. This means there are a couple
of places in 'HostState' and 'HostManager', which uses 'HostState',
where we need to handle these strings.

Simplify this whole mess by ensuring 'HostState.numa_topology' is always
an object. This isn't quite as clean as we'd like (it would be be better
if 'ComputeNode.numa_topology' was an object too) but it gives us a path
forward to removing a lot of the "string or object to object" helper
functions we have in the future.

Change-Id: I2d6514205aab4282196e6bddabafaf07beb3a4a3
'}]
commit_message:
WIP: Ensure 'HostState.numa_topology' is always an object

The 'HostState.update' function is called by
'HostManager._get_computes_for_cells' with a 'ComputeNode' object as its
first argument. The 'HostState.numa_topology' attribute is set to the
value of the 'numa_topology' attribute for this 'ComputeNode' object.
However, for legacy reasons, the 'ComputeNode.numa_topology' attribute
is currently a string representation of a 'NUMATopology' object, which
must then be converted into a real object. This means there are a couple
of places in 'HostState' and 'HostManager', which uses 'HostState',
where we need to handle these strings.

Simplify this whole mess by ensuring 'HostState.numa_topology' is always
an object. This isn't quite as clean as we'd like (it would be be better
if 'ComputeNode.numa_topology' was an object too) but it gives us a path
forward to removing a lot of the "string or object to object" helper
functions we have in the future.

Change-Id: I2d6514205aab4282196e6bddabafaf07beb3a4a3

which means that it has to explicity reference pacemaker::params::*

which means that it has to explicity reference pacemaker::params::*
variables and cannot directly reference them as pacemaker::* vars.

This fixes errors like:
puppet-user[13745]: Error: Validation of File_line[pcsd_bind_addr]

commit_message:
Fix params in pcmk remote

The pacemaker::remote class does not inherit from the pacemaker class
which means that it has to explicity reference pacemaker::params::*
variables and cannot directly reference them as pacemaker::* vars.

This fixes errors like:
puppet-user[13745]: Error: Validation of File_line[pcsd_bind_addr]
  failed: path is a required attribute (file: /etc/puppet/modules/pacemaker/manifests/remote.pp, line: 89)

Related-Bug: #1861668

Change-Id: I393fc032314139dcd4254dc66a4f594ca4fe2891

commit_message:
Fix variable checks in install-deps

A couple of fixes:
- We check the content of the binary dir as debug step, but this
should be necessary only when in virtualenv.
Also using the correct virtualenv path instead of hardcoding it,
and removing - character after variable name.
- EXTRA_PKG_DEPS is an array and we should treat it like that
when we check if it's empty or not.

commit_message:
Fix for getting port groups while using OVS up to 2.9

Functions get_port_group() and get_port_groups() were failing
with KeyError while getting to access non-existent Port_Group
table with OVS 2.9.

This patch adds additional check if Port Group is supported in the
env where the code runs.

Change-Id: If3ce6ab1d1318a6d5142989b3bf45ecce97762e3
Closes-Bug: #1844491

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-31 15:51:19.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure no sg rule is repeated on the Network Policy CRD

The use of python index to indentify the sg rules that are meant to be kept on
the CRD is not ideal when sg rules are repeated on a CRD. In case of repeated rules
on the list of existent rules, only the first ocurrence of the rule get the ID back,
and the sg rule on the list of current sg rules does not get to be created because
there is the same rule (without the ID) on the existent rules list, causing the CRD
to not be updated, as there is a rule with no ID.
This commit fixes the issue by ensuring that no sg rule is repeated on the NP CRD.

Change-Id: I5170e0177a87c2dde77f19f6a7ae09ca2a06c65e
'}, {'created': '2020-01-31 15:52:41.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure no sg rule is repeated on the Network Policy CRD

The use of python index to indentify the sg rules that are meant to be
kept on the CRD is not ideal when sg rules are repeated on a CRD.
In case of repeated rules on the list of existent rules, only the first
ocurrence of the rule get the ID back, and the sg rule on the list of
current sg rules does not get to be created because there is the same
rule (without the ID) on the existent rules list, causing the CRD to not
be updated, as there is a rule with no ID.
This commit fixes the issue by ensuring that no sg rule is repeated
on the NP CRD.

Change-Id: I5170e0177a87c2dde77f19f6a7ae09ca2a06c65e
'}, {'created': '2020-01-31 16:08:09.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure no sg rule is repeated on the Network Policy CRD

When a network policy is updated we compare all the existing sg rules
with the current sg rules in order to add/remove rules.
When there are existing rules repeated only the first occurence
of the rule is identified as to be kept, and the second one
is not, causing the rule on the current sg rules to not be created,
as it matches an existent sg rule that was not meant to be kept,
causing a breakage on the update NP CRD which does not allow sg rules
with no ID.

This commit fixes the issue by ensuring that no sg rule is repeated
on the NP CRD.

Change-Id: I5170e0177a87c2dde77f19f6a7ae09ca2a06c65e
'}, {'created': '2020-02-02 18:18:02.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure no sg rule is repeated on the Network Policy CRD

When a network policy is updated we compare all the existing sg rules
with the current sg rules in order to add/remove rules.
When there are existing rules repeated only the first occurence
of the rule is identified as to be kept, and the second one
is not, causing the rule on the current sg rules to not be created,
as it matches an existent sg rule that was not meant to be kept,
causing a breakage on the update NP CRD which does not allow sg rules
with no ID.

This commit fixes the issue by ensuring that no sg rule is repeated
on the NP CRD.

Closes-bug: 1861624

Change-Id: I5170e0177a87c2dde77f19f6a7ae09ca2a06c65e
'}]
commit_message:
Ensure no sg rule is repeated on the Network Policy CRD

When a network policy is updated we compare all the existing sg rules
with the current sg rules in order to add/remove rules.
When there are existing rules repeated only the first occurence
of the rule is identified as to be kept, and the second one
is not, causing the rule on the current sg rules to not be created,
as it matches an existent sg rule that was not meant to be kept,
causing a breakage on the update NP CRD which does not allow sg rules
with no ID.

This commit fixes the issue by ensuring that no sg rule is repeated
on the NP CRD.

Closes-bug: 1861624

Change-Id: I5170e0177a87c2dde77f19f6a7ae09ca2a06c65e

commit_message:
Unmask services during post-series-upgrade

If a unit is paused then its services will not start during the
post-series-upgrade hook. In addition exclude haproxy from the list
of services to start if it is being managed by hacluster.

Closes-Bug: #1861660
Change-Id: I5f72f5507b9ed40b50dcacd1940e91d3cff26298

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-29 19:15:55.000000000', 'message': "Remove the tripleo_job_ansible_args default

This change removes the default '-v' from the environment variable when executing
local tests. This was done to enhance output for the end user by default but the
side effect was that not scenario tests were being executed. This change will ensure
any developers running the local tests are getting the same output we'd expect in
upstream zuul.

Change-Id: I76a1e44cea8140a6760e21946d62a0ecac368a24
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Remove the tripleo_job_ansible_args default

This change removes the default '-v' from the environment variable when executing
local tests. This was done to enhance output for the end user by default but the
side effect was that not scenario tests were being executed. This change will ensure
any developers running the local tests are getting the same output we'd expect in
upstream zuul.

Change-Id: I76a1e44cea8140a6760e21946d62a0ecac368a24
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Create role for molecule prep

Since we need to install the collection (and possibly other actions in
the future), let's create a role that we can share across all the tests.

commit_message:
[ussuri][goal] Drop python 2.7 support and testing

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

Complete discussion & schedule can be found in
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010142.html
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Change-Id: Ie1e6a0b1aac4aca3f7f6a3ef7113ceee28233463

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-19 22:22:07.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Ensure CRL is on the haproxy container

When haproxy was containerized, the CRL wasn't properly mounted on the
container. This can cause an issue if the certificates used for TLS
are revoked by the CA.

This commit adds the CRL to the mount path for haproxy.

Change-Id: I913823dff3e2a7141a5136d56dc60b9d27c5fc9a
"}, {'created': '2019-12-20 20:28:44.000000000', 'message': "Ensure CRL is on the haproxy container

When haproxy was containerized, the CRL wasn't properly mounted on the
container. According to previous notes and patches, it sounds like
this was due to the inability to restart haproxy when the current CRL
expired. If the CRL isn't mounted on the container we can have issues
with the validity of the certificates used for TLS if they're infact
revoked.

Additional context:
  If307e3357dccb7e96bdb80c9c06d66a09b55f3bd
  Ic6ca88ee7b6b256ae6182e60e07498a8a793d66a

This commit adds the CRL to the mount path for haproxy.

Change-Id: I913823dff3e2a7141a5136d56dc60b9d27c5fc9a
"}]
commit_message:
Ensure CRL is on the haproxy container

When haproxy was containerized, the CRL wasn't properly mounted on the
container. According to previous notes and patches, it sounds like
this was due to the inability to restart haproxy when the current CRL
expired. If the CRL isn't mounted on the container we can have issues
with the validity of the certificates used for TLS if they're infact
revoked.

Additional context:
  If307e3357dccb7e96bdb80c9c06d66a09b55f3bd
  Ic6ca88ee7b6b256ae6182e60e07498a8a793d66a

This commit adds the CRL to the mount path for haproxy.

Change-Id: I913823dff3e2a7141a5136d56dc60b9d27c5fc9a

commit_message:
[WIP] Create 'mixed' instance from PCPU and VCPU resources

Creating the 'mixed' instance if both 'PCPU' and 'VCPU' resources
have been provided in flavor extra specs.

Part of blueprint use-pcpu-and-vcpu-in-one-instance

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-26 02:18:57.000000000', 'message': "More tests for validating CPU policy by 'resources:PCPU' and 'resources:VCPU'

Commit 278ab01c32 introduces the way to create instance CPU allocation
policy through 'resources:PCPU' or 'resources:VCPU', without an
explicit define of 'hw:cpu_policy' or 'hw_cpu_policy' in flavor or image
metadata.

It is also possible to create the instance with multiple NUMA nodes and
specify cpu policy in this way. This patch add more tests to validate
the operation of creating such kind of instance.

Change-Id: I2536924bfa9068603518b68fe969e0ed67cbd645
"}, {'created': '2020-01-29 04:57:55.000000000', 'message': "[WIP] More tests for validating CPU policy by 'resources:PCPU' and 'resources:VCPU'

policy through 'resources:PCPU' or 'resources:VCPU', without an
explicit define of 'hw:cpu_policy' or 'hw_cpu_policy' in flavor or image

This patch add more tests to validate the operation of creating instance
with multiple NUMA cells.

Change-Id: I2536924bfa9068603518b68fe969e0ed67cbd645
"}]
commit_message:
[WIP] More tests for validating CPU policy by 'resources:PCPU' and 'resources:VCPU'

Commit 278ab01c32 introduces the way to create instance CPU allocation
policy through 'resources:PCPU' or 'resources:VCPU', without an
explicit define of 'hw:cpu_policy' or 'hw_cpu_policy' in flavor or image
metadata.

This patch add more tests to validate the operation of creating instance
with multiple NUMA cells.

Change-Id: I2536924bfa9068603518b68fe969e0ed67cbd645

commit_message:
[WIP] Refactor the code path of creating instance with a NUMA topology

For an instance demanding huge pages or persist memory or pinned
vCPU or having an explicit setting of requiring a 'numa_nodes',
there is a NUMA topology. And the code for creating the topology
could be centralized in one place.

Refactoring and centralizing these code in one place.

Part of blueprint use-pcpu-and-vcpu-in-one-instance

Change-Id: I664a33b26df3e65ef92900fa8717af7b5b200a08

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-16 13:48:54.000000000', 'message': "[WIP] Assign and track instance pinning cpu through 'cpu_pinning' field

The InstanceNUMACell.cpu_pinning is special for recording the
'vcpu' and 'pcpu' pair for the instance pinned vcpus.

This patch makes it possible to assign partial instance NUMA cell vcpus
be the pinned CPU, instead of all CPUs in a cell to be the pinned CPUs
or un-pinned CPUs.

Change-Id: I7a28a293d71d4aa96f4620d82bc54bcbe2520cb2
"}, {'created': '2019-10-17 13:17:49.000000000', 'message': "Assign and track instance pinning cpu through 'cpu_pinning' field

The InstanceNUMACell.cpu_pinning is special for recording the
'vcpu' and 'pcpu' pair for the instance pinned vcpus.

This patch makes it possible to assign partial instance NUMA cell vcpus
be the pinned CPU, instead of all CPUs in a cell to be the pinned CPUs
or un-pinned CPUs.

The InstanceNUMACell.cpu_pinning is special for recording the
'vcpu' and 'pcpu' pair for the instance pinned vcpus.

This patch makes it possible to assign partial instance NUMA cell vcpus
be the pinned CPU, instead of all CPUs in a cell to be the pinned CPUs
or un-pinned CPUs.

Part of blueprint use-pcpu-and-vcpu-in-one-instance

`InstanceNUMACell.cpu_pinning` is used to track the information
of pinned CPU pair, the 'vcpu' and the 'pcpu', which was
initialized after the instance NUMA cell object is created due
to fact that all instance CPUs have the same allocation policy.

commit_message:
[WIP] Assign instance dedicated CPU set through `cpu_pinning` field

`InstanceNUMACell.cpu_pinning` is used to track the information
of pinned CPU pair, the 'vcpu' and the 'pcpu', which was
initialized after the instance NUMA cell object is created due
to fact that all instance CPUs have the same allocation policy.

The upcoming 'mixed' CPU allocation policy will introduce the
concept that CPUs inside one instance could have different
allocation policy, some CPU would be 'dedicated' CPU and some
would be the 'shared' CPU.

This patch initializes the information of instance dedicated CPU
set by setting the 'dedicated' CPU id in `cpu_pinning` field
before the stage of scheduling instance to real host node.

Part of blueprint use-pcpu-and-vcpu-in-one-instance

Change-Id: I7a28a293d71d4aa96f4620d82bc54bcbe2520cb2

commit_message:
[WIP] Introduce a new instance CPU allocation policy: mixed

The 'mixed' instance CPU allocation policy is for creating an instance
to have 'mixed' CPU priorities in such way that some instance CPUs
are pinned on host PCPU resource and others are floating on the VCPU
resources.

Part of blueprint use-pcpu-and-vcpu-in-one-instance

Change-Id: Ia9756c35799aaac8b13eab5605ec6c7710d0c8dc

commit_message:
[WIP] support unbalanced dedicatd CPU distribution on instance NUMA nodes

Just like unbalanced instance CPU and memory distribution on NUMA nodes,
introduced the unbalanced dedicated CPU distribution on NUMA nodes.

Part of blueprint use-pcpu-and-vcpu-in-one-instance

Change-Id: Ia04449d604353b4b4493bac8c324f8d56ec2ac19

commit_message:
load_config: allow the config to be overriden

This will enable an operator using the paunch Ansible module to override
any container parameter e.g. the image, directly from Ansible without
modifying the config that is on the host.

Change-Id: I6639ab859b120aa9349dc72b0d6e7d575be20c7a

commit_message:
Deprecate unmaintaned features

Support for OpenShift Routes (Ingress) is not maintained by anyone, not
really tested and there are better ways to do it, so let's remove that
code from Kuryr.

Support for namespace isolation was done to mimic one of the modes of
openshift-sdn. It doesn't seem to make any sense to keep supporting it
if Network Policy support can provide the same isolation.

Change-Id: I8cfb3c50f491a5dbbfe6fa20b81ee1d0f8c6b4a7

commit_message:
Fix artcl_gzip variable in infrared plugin spec

Setting artcl_gzip_only in infrared to true has no effect as
the variable name used in the tasks is artcl_gzip.

Change-Id: Ifb1ff58b14fc9306f5e6ba3a49c60619331d6e02

Change-Id: I24fcecd9686ad17fa50093bb8bccab0d6c711298

commit_message:
Remove L3 IP QoS cache when router is down

When router admin-state is down or removed, fip-qos and gateway-ip-qos
extension should delete the router IPs' QoS rate limit cache. Then if
the router is up again the router floating IPs QoS can be reconfigured.
This patch achives these:
1. make sure floating IP or gateway IP QoS cache removed.
2. floating IP QoS can be re-configured to snat device when router
   doing admin_state down/up.

Conflicts:
    neutron/agent/l3/extensions/fip_qos.py

Closes-Bug: #1826695
Change-Id: I24fcecd9686ad17fa50093bb8bccab0d6c711298
(cherry picked from commit 78629e0d3780af4a8a8cc1b5b0762e0bc8a48f1f)
(cherry picked from commit 3489ce72c31a6df2bb845ee10a61625250ff6a94)

commit_message:
Use spawn method for multiprocessing

In python3 there may be issues [0] with using the fork()
method for starting image uploader workers.

Let's use spawn() instead that starts new processes from a scratch.

[0] https://codewithoutrules.com/2018/09/04/python-multiprocessing/

Closes-bug: #1852996

Change-Id: I9fd8276c0a1286a7470aafe12a1c591eb83f9fa5
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-05 12:26:03.000000000', 'message': "Wire-in Apache MPM module parameters and switch it

Allow to configure Apache MPM module for the containerized API/WSGI'ish
services running Apache as a backend. Change the default from 'prefork'
to 'event', which is a low level change and should provide no sensible
upgrade impact. This alleviates the related heartbeats threading issue
arising with the monkey-patched eventlet.

Merge the missing ApacheServiceBase config settings for Octavia API,
Horizon and Ironix PXE. This is needed to apply the base Apache
service hiera settings, including MPM module switches, for those
as well.

Related-bug: #1829062

Change-Id: I2f4321c6e05c1f3c6da2f839e13e7797356690c6
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

Wire-in Apache MPM module parameters and switch it

Allow to configure Apache MPM module for the containerized API/WSGI'ish
services running Apache as a backend. Change the default from 'prefork'
to 'event', which is a low level change and should provide no sensible
upgrade impact. This alleviates the related heartbeats threading issue
arising with the monkey-patched eventlet.

Merge the missing ApacheServiceBase config settings for Octavia API,
Horizon and Ironix PXE. This is needed to apply the base Apache
service hiera settings, including MPM module switches, for those
as well.

Related-bug: #1829062

Change-Id: I2f4321c6e05c1f3c6da2f839e13e7797356690c6
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-05 12:26:03.000000000', 'message': "Fix generating Apache configs by container-puppet

W/o this change /etc/httpd/conf.d/00-mpm.conf
(/etc/httpd/conf.modules.d/00-mpm.conf for RHEL OS family 7) shipped
with RPM or other conflicting httpd modules might remain in the
containers and cause startup failures. While puppet removes such
conflicts from the configuration, f.e. when switching MPM 'prefork' to
'event', and we expect it never gets into container configs.

Make kolla extended start properly enforcing the wanted state of
/etc/httpd for WSGI-based API services. We rely on the puppet base
profiles of those services to include the required apache configs.

Also, noop service resources for puppet step config via
the common puppet step config manifest.

Related-Bug: #1829062
Related-bug: #1838972
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/674069

Change-Id: I9e47e85e18c9a6e4fb44d3e6b6b6d62a21d6f2b5
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
